CITY ORGANIZATION AND INCORPORATION
§ 10.01 NOTICE OF PETITION TO INCORPORATE.
   Notice is hereby given that on Monday, October 1, 1888, the undersigned will
make application to the County Board of County Commissioners for the
incorporation as a town to be named Rock Springs of the following described
territory: all that portion of land included in the north half and southwest
quarter of Section 25, south half of Section 26, north half of Section 35,
containing an area of two square miles and situated in Township 19 North, Range
105 West, in the County of Sweetwater and Territory of Wyoming. The survey and
map of said territory and the census of the resident population thereof, made
and taken as required by law, may be examined at the post office in the city.
(Prior Code, § 1-101)
§ 10.02 ORGANIZATION OF THE CITY.
   (A)   An application being made to the County Board by petition, asking that
an order be issued declaring that the territory included in the boundary lines
set forth in the survey and map presented with the petition shall be an
incorporated town, the County Board, after hearing all persons who came before
them respecting such application, being fully satisfied that all the
requirements in Wyo. Stat. Chapter 12, relating to the general incorporations
of towns, had been complied with, on motion.
   (B)   The territory described on map presented with petition shall be an
incorporated town, known as Rock Springs, and do appoint Messrs. H. F. Menough,
Wm. H. O’Donnell and Thomas Sutton to act as inspectors of election, to hold
the first election on November 13, 1888, for the purpose of electing town
officers.
(Prior Code, § 1-102)
§ 10.03 FIRST ELECTION.
   (A)   Proceeding upon the order of the Board of County Commissioners, the
first election of the incorporated town of Rock Springs was held on November
13, 1888, and resulted in the election of the following officers: Mayor, W. H.
O’Donnell; Council members, H. H. Edgar, Edward Thorpe, Augustine Kendall and
N. C. Peterson.
   (B)   The Mayor and Council members so elected held their first meeting on
November 19, 1888, and proceeded to appoint officers, adopt ordinances and
transact generally the business of the town.
(Prior Code, § 1-103)
§ 10.04 CITY OF THE FIRST CLASS.
   The Mayor of said town is hereby authorized and empowered to ascertain and
certify to the Governor, under and by virtue of his or her official
certificate, attested by the seal of said town, the population of the town, for
the purpose of having the Governor, if it be ascertained that said town has
attained a population of more than 4,000 inhabitants, declare by public
proclamation said Town of Rock Springs to be a city of the first class and
subject to the provisions of Wyo. Stat. Chapter 121, as amended by subsequent
acts of the legislature of the state, with all the powers and obligations
pertaining thereto.
(Prior Code, § 1-104)
§ 10.05 PROCLAMATION.
   (A)   The Town Council of the Town of Rock Springs of the State of Wyoming,
on July 21, 1919, at a regular meeting of said Council, duly and legally passed
a resolution authorizing and empowering the Mayor of said town to ascertain and
certify to the Governor that the population of said town was found to be more
than 4,000 inhabitants.
   (B)   The duly elected and qualified Mayor has ascertained and certified
that the Town of Rock Springs has more than 4,000 inhabitants.
   (C)   The Governor has proclaimed and declared the Town of Rock Springs to
be a city of the first class and subject to the provisions of Wyo. Stat.
Chapter 121.
(Prior Code, § 1-105)
§ 10.06 ORGANIZATION OF THE CITY AS A CITY OF THE FIRST CLASS.
   The City of Rock Springs, in the County of Sweetwater, State of Wyoming, a
municipal corporation, was heretofore organized and is now existing by virtue
of the general incorporation laws of the state, Wyo. Stat. Chapter 120, as
amended by subsequent acts of the legislature of said state.
(Prior Code, § 1-106)
RULES OF CONSTRUCTION
§ 10.20 ADOPTION.
   From and after the adoption of this code by ordinance and its due
publication, said code shall be and constitute the “Revised Ordinances of the
City of Rock Springs, Wyoming.”
(Prior Code, § 14-101) (Ord. 1979, passed - -; Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.21 ORDINANCES INCLUDED IN CODE.
   All ordinances of a private, local and temporary nature, including
franchises, grants, dedications, special levies for local assessments,
ordinances creating paving districts, bond issues, occupational tax ordinances,
resolutions authorizing the signing of contracts and all other ordinances and
resolutions which have to be passed yearly or periodically, shall not be
included in this code, but shall remain in full force and effect, and the City
Clerk is directed to have the original of said ordinances and resolutions
available for inspection at all times.
(Prior Code, § 14-102) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.22 REPEAL OF EXISTING ORDINANCES.
    All ordinances of a general nature in force and which are not included in
this code, or which are not herein expressly continued in force by §
10.21, are hereby repealed.
(Prior Code, § 14-103) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.23 EFFECT OF REPEALING ORDINANCES.
   The repeal of ordinances, as provided in §
10.22, shall not affect any act done or any right accruing or any suit or
proceeding had or commenced in any civil or criminal cause before said repeal,
but all rights and liabilities under said ordinances shall continue and be in
force in the same manner as if said repeal had not been made, and all offenses
committed and all penalties and forfeitures incurred under any ordinance hereby
repealed may be prosecuted and punished in the same manner and with the same
effect as if said repeal had not been made; and that the repeal of any
ordinance shall not thereby have the effect of reviving any ordinance
theretofore repealed or superseded.
(Prior Code, § 14-104) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.24 RULES FOR CONSTRUCTION; DEFINITIONS.
   In the construction of this code and all ordinances amendatory thereof or
supplementary thereto, the following rules shall be observed unless such
construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the legislative
body or repugnant to the contest of the ordinance.
   (A)   The singular number includes the plural. Words used in the present
tense include the future. Words used in the masculine gender in this code or in
other ordinances of the city include the feminine and neuter.
   (B)   Words prohibiting anything being done, except in accordance with a
license or permit or authority from a board or officers, shall be construed as
giving such board or officer power to license or permit or authorize such thing
to be done.
   (C)   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      CITY. The City of Rock Springs, Wyoming.
      COUNTY. The County of Sweetwater.
      KNOWINGLY. This term imparts only a knowledge that the facts exist which
bring the act or omission within the provisions of this code. It does not
require any knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
      LAND, REAL ESTATE and REAL PROPERTY. Include lands, tenements,
hereditaments, water rights, possessory rights and claims.
      MONTH. A calendar month unless otherwise expressed, and the word YEAR or
the abbreviation A.D. is equivalent to the expression “Year of Our Lord.”
      NEGLECT, NEGLIGENCE, NEGLIGENT and NEGLIGENTLY. These terms impart a want
of such attention to the nature or probable consequences of the act or omission
as a prudent person ordinarily bestows in acting in his or her own concern.
      OATH. Includes AFFIRMATION and the word SWEAR includes the word AFFIRM.
Every mode of oral statement under oath or affirmation is embraced in the term
TESTIFY and every written one in the term DEPOSE.
      OFFICER. Includes officers and boards in charge of departments and the
members of such boards.
      OWNER. As applied to a building or land, any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of such
building or land.
      PERSON. Includes bodies politic and corporate partnerships, associations
and corporations.
      PERSONAL PROPERTY. Includes every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished, and every right or
interest therein.
      PROPERTY. Includes both real and personal property.
      SIGNATURE. Includes any name, mark or sign written with the intent to
authenticate any instrument or writing.
      STATE. The State of Wyoming.
      STREET. Includes alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
      TENANT or OCCUPANT. As applied to a building or land, any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land either alone or with
others.
      WILLFULLY. When applied to the intent with which an act is done or
omitted, implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or make the
omission referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to
injure another, or to acquire any advantage.
      WRITING. Includes printing, writing and typewriting.
   (D)   When any time is specified in this code, it shall mean standard time,
as distinguished from solar time, and the words MIDNIGHT or NOON shall be taken
to be midnight or noon standard time.
(Prior Code, § 14-105) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.25 INTENT TO DEFRAUD.
   Whenever by any of the provisions of this code an intent to defraud is
required in order to constitute any offense, it is sufficient if an intent
appears to defraud any person, association or body politic or corporate
whatever.
(Prior Code, § 14-106) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.26 LIABILITY OF EMPLOYERS AND AGENTS.
   When the provisions of any section of this code prohibit the commission or
omission of an act, not only the person actually doing the prohibited thing or
omitting the directed act, but also the employer and all other persons
concerned or aiding or abetting therein, shall be guilty of the offense
described and liable to the penalty prescribed for the offense.
(Prior Code, § 14-107) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.27 TO WHAT ACTS PENALTY SHALL ATTACH.
   Any person who shall commit any act declared by any section of this code or
any ordinance of the city to be unlawful, or any act which is forbidden by
ordinance, or who fails to perform any act or discharge any obligation or duty
required by or imposed upon him or her by any ordinance shall be deemed guilty
of violating such ordinance and shall be subject to the penalty fixed for the
violation of any city ordinance with like effect as if such penalty were
specifically declared in the section or provision of the ordinance forbidding
such act or declaring the same to be unlawful or prescribing the duty or
imposing the obligation, and where any duty is prescribed or obligation
imposed, or where any act is of a continuing nature is forbidden or declared to
be unlawful, each day such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act
continues shall constitute a separate offense except where otherwise provided
in this code.
(Prior Code, § 14-108) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.28 TITLES OF SECTIONS AND DIVISIONS NOT RESTRICTED.
   The title of any section or division of this code shall be deemed to in no
way restrict or qualify or to limit the effect of the provisions set forth and
contained in such section or division.
(Prior Code, § 14-110) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.29 CONSTITUTIONALITY; EFFECT OF.
   Should any section, division or portion of this code, or of any ordinance
which may be hereafter passed, approved and published, as required by law, be
declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or void,
such adjudication shall in no way affect the remaining portion of such section,
division, part or portion of this code or of any such ordinance hereafter
passed, approved and published.
(Prior Code, § 14-111) (Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964)
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   (A)   (1)   Whenever in this code or any ordinance of the city an act is
prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a
misdemeanor, or whenever in such code or ordinance the doing of any act is
required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, regardless of
whether a specific penalty for such act or failure to act has heretofore been
established by any other ordinance, the violation of any such provision of this
code or any such ordinance shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $750,
a jail sentence of not more than six months, or both, to which restitution may
be added by the trial court. Each day any violation of this code or any
ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. If any such
violation is designated as a nuisance under the provisions of this code, such
nuisance may be summarily abated by the Police Department of the city, or a
citation may be issued and the violator punished in accordance with this
section. In addition to any fine imposed under this section, such violator may
be taxed for court costs or such other administrative fees as the court deems
necessary for all ordinance violations.
      (2)   This general penalty provision is intended to and shall supersede
all other penalty provisions heretofore enacted except as specifically provided
hereafter.
      (3)   Provided, however, that this uniform penalty provision shall not
apply to the specific penalties provided for within ordinances as civil
penalties.
      (4)   Provided, however, that this uniform penalty provision shall not
apply to offenses adopted by the city pursuant to §
70.01 that are not otherwise punishable by incarceration under state law, and
for those offenses the maximum penalty shall not exceed a fine of $750.
      (5)   Provided, however, that this uniform penalty provision shall not
apply to violations of the following code sections: §§
90.03;
90.05;
90.06;
90.07;
90.08;
90.11;
90.12;
90.15;
90.16;
90.18;
90.19;
111.01;
111.05;
113.01;
130.03;
130.05;
131.004;
131.045;
131.068;
131.070;
132.002;
132.003;
132.004;
132.015;
133.12;
133.14; and
157.007. The penalty for these offenses shall not exceed a maximum fine of
$750.
(Prior Code, § 2-101.1)
   (B)   Any person who shall violate any ordinance or any provision of any
ordinance of the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be fined in any sum not more than $100, to which may
be added the costs at the discretion of the court; and in default of the
payment of such fine and costs, be confined in the City Jail at the rate of one
day for each $1.50 of the fine and costs so imposed, and while so confined, may
be required to work on any street, alley or other public work of this city for
the benefit of this city.
(Prior Code, § 14-109)
(Ord. 1612, passed 8-31-1964; Ord. 83-12, passed 6-7-1983; Ord. 89-24, passed
11-7-1989; Ord. 2007-02, passed 3-6-2007; Ord. 2021-12, passed 10-5-2021)
CHAPTER 11: CITY STANDARDS
Section
   
11.01   Four Wards established
   
11.02   First Ward
   
11.03   Second Ward
   
11.04   Third Ward
   
11.05   Fourth Ward
   
11.06   Seal of the city
§ 11.01 FOUR WARDS ESTABLISHED.
   The City of Rock Springs, Sweetwater County, Wyoming, is hereby divided into
four wards, called: “First Ward,” “Second Ward,” “Third Ward” and “Fourth
Ward,” the boundaries of which shall be as hereinafter specified, each of said
wards having at least 1,000 inhabitants. The ward boundaries shall conform to
and coincide with the 2002 voter precinct boundaries as established by the
office of the County Clerk in the Voter Precinct and Ward Map and legal
descriptions, a copy of which is attached to the ordinance codified in this
chapter and incorporated herein by this reference. In particular, the First
Ward shall include voter precincts 04-1, 04-2, 04-3 and 04-4; the Second Ward
shall include voter precincts 05-1, 05-2 and 05-3; the Third Ward shall include
voter precincts 06-1, 06-2, 06-3 and 06-4; and the Fourth Ward shall include
voter precincts 03-1, 03-2, 03-3, 03-4 and 03-5.
(Prior Code, § 1-301) (Ord. 1351, passed - -; Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963,
passed - -; Ord. 177, passed 9-22-1919)
§ 11.02 FIRST WARD.
   The First Ward shall include all that area lying within the city, being more
particularly described as follows:
   (A)   Beginning at the intersection of C Street and Union Pacific Railroad
mainline track; thence southeasterly along C Street to Reed Street; thence
northeasterly and northerly along Reed Street to D Street; thence easterly
along D Street to Massachusetts Avenue; thence southerly along Massachusetts
Avenue to Wyoming Street; thence easterly along Wyoming Street to Washington
Avenue; thence southerly and southwesterly along Washington Avenue to Willow
Street; thence westerly along Willow Street to Walnut Street; thence northerly
along Walnut Street to Alder Street; thence westerly along Alder Street to
Blair Avenue; thence southwesterly along Blair Avenue to the Rock Springs South
Belt Route; thence westerly along said Belt Route to Dewar Drive; thence
northeasterly along Dewar Drive to the Reliance spur track of the Union Pacific
Railroad; thence southerly along said spur track to the junction of the Union
Pacific Railroad mainline track; thence northeasterly along said mainline track
to the point of beginning;
   (B)   Beginning at the intersection of Sweetwater Drive and the westerly
boundary of the corporate limits to said city; thence northeasterly along
Sweetwater Drive to Dewar Drive; thence southeasterly along Dewar Drive to
Sunset Drive; thence southwesterly along Sunset Drive to the corporate boundary
of said city; thence beginning northerly and continuing along said corporate
boundary to the point of beginning;
   (C)   Beginning at the intersection of the south boundary of the county and
State Highway 430; thence westerly along said county boundary to the east bank
of the Flaming Gorge Reservoir; thence northerly along said east bank and the
east bank of the Green River to the easterly boundary of the incorporated
limits to the City of Green River; thence northerly along said city boundary to
the Bitter Creek drainage; thence northeasterly along said drainage to U.S.
Highway 191; thence southerly along said highway to the junction of County Road
4-51; thence northeasterly along said county road to the westerly boundary of
the incorporated limits to the city; thence beginning westerly and continuing
along said corporate boundary to Sunset Boulevard; thence easterly along Sunset
Boulevard to Dewar Drive; thence easterly along Dewar Drive to the Rock Springs
South Belt Route; thence southeasterly along said belt route to the south
boundary of the incorporated limits to the city; thence easterly along said
south boundary to the southeast corner of said incorporated limits; thence
northerly along the easterly boundary of said incorporated limits to State
Highway 430; thence southeasterly along said highway to the junction of County
Road 4-26; thence easterly and southeasterly along said county road to County
Road 4-24; thence northeasterly along said County Road 4-24 to the junction of
County Road 4-19; thence southerly and southwesterly along said County Road 4-
19 to State Highway 430; thence southerly along said highway to the point of
beginning; and
   (D)   Beginning at the junction of State Highway 430 and Marchant Street;
thence southeasterly along said highway to the corporate boundary of the city;
thence southerly and westerly to the Southside Belt Route; thence northwesterly
along said belt route to West Blair Avenue; thence northeasterly along West
Blair Avenue to Alder Street; thence easterly along Alder Street to Walnut
Street; thence southerly along Walnut Street to Willow Street; thence easterly
along Willow Street to Thompson Street; thence continuing easterly along
Thompson Street to the easterly fence line of the Municipal Cemetery; thence
southerly along said fence line to Marchant Street; thence easterly along
Marchant Street to Lincoln Avenue; thence southerly along Lincoln Avenue to
Fancher Street; thence easterly along Fancher Street to Adams Avenue; thence
northerly along Adams Avenue to Marchant Street; thence easterly and
northeasterly along Marchant Street to the point of beginning.
(Prior Code, § 1-302) (Ord. 1351, passed - -; Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963,
passed - -; Ord. 177, passed 9-22-1919; Ord. 76-21, passed 6-15-1976; Ord. 92-
13, passed 5-5-1992)
§ 11.03 SECOND WARD.
   The Second Ward shall include all that area lying within the city, being
more particularly described as follows:
   (A)   Beginning at the intersection of Dewar Drive and Gateway Boulevard;
thence northerly along Gateway Boulevard to Skyline Drive; thence easterly and
northeasterly along Skyline Drive to College Drive; thence northerly
approximately 0.4 miles along said College Drive to an overhead high-voltage
power transmission line crossing; thence northeasterly along said powerline to
the Reliance spur track of the Union Pacific Railroad; thence southerly along
said spur track to Center Street; thence southwesterly, westerly and
northwesterly along Center Street and Dewar Drive to the point of beginning;
   (B)   Beginning at the intersection of Sweetwater Drive and Dewar Drive;
thence northeasterly along Sweetwater Drive to Reagan Avenue; thence easterly
along Reagan Avenue to Foothill Boulevard; thence southerly along Foothill
Boulevard to Truman Street; thence easterly along said Truman Street to Madison
Drive; thence northeasterly along Madison Drive to College Drive; thence
southeasterly along College Drive to Skyline Drive; thence southwesterly along
Skyline Drive to Gateway Boulevard; thence southerly along Gateway Boulevard to
Dewar Drive; thence northwesterly along Dewar Drive to the point of beginning;
and
   (C)   Beginning at the intersection of Sweetwater Drive and the westerly
boundary of the corporate limits to said city; thence northerly along said
corporate boundary to the crossing of the buried water pipeline serving the Jim
Bridger Power Plant; thence northeasterly along said buried pipeline to
Foothill Boulevard; thence southerly along Foothill Boulevard to Stagecoach
Boulevard; thence northeasterly along Stagecoach Boulevard to the Reliance spur
track of the Union Pacific Railroad; thence southerly along said track to the
centerline of U.S. Interstate 80; thence southwesterly along Interstate 80 to
the College Drive junction; thence westerly along College Drive to Madison
Drive; thence southwesterly along Madison Drive to Truman Street; thence
westerly along Truman Street to Foothill Boulevard; thence northerly along
Foothill Boulevard to Reagan Avenue; thence westerly along Reagan Avenue to
Sweetwater Drive; thence southwesterly along Sweetwater Drive to the point of
beginning.
(Prior Code, § 1-303) (Ord. 1351, passed - -; Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963,
passed - -; Ord. 177, passed 9-22-1919; Ord. 76-21, passed 6-15-1976; Ord. 92-
13, passed 5-5-1992)
§ 11.04 THIRD WARD.
   The Third Ward shall include all that area lying within the city, being more
particularly described as follows:
   (A)   Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of U.S. Interstate 80
and the Reliance spur track of the Union Pacific Railroad; thence northeasterly
along said interstate centerline to the corporate boundary to the city; thence
southerly and easterly along said corporate boundary to the centerline of U.S.
Interstate 80; thence southeasterly along said interstate centerline to the
crossing of Swanson Drive; thence southwesterly along Swanson Drive to Ninth
Street; thence northwesterly along Ninth Street to the Rock Springs Belt Route;
thence southerly along said Belt Route to the westbound track of the Union
Pacific Railroad mainline; thence southwesterly along said track to the Pearl
Street Diversion Canal crossing; thence northeasterly and northerly along said
diversion canal to the confluence of Bitter Creek; thence easterly along Bitter
Creek to Pilot Butte Avenue; thence southwesterly along Pilot Butte Avenue,
Bridger Avenue and Center Street to the Reliance spur track of the Union
Pacific Railroad; thence northwesterly along said track to the point of
beginning;
   (B)   Together with and including all that area lying within the corporate
boundaries of the Municipal Airport;
   (C)   Beginning at the intersection of the Reliance spur track of the Union
Pacific Railroad and the centerline of U.S. Interstate 80; thence northerly
along said spur track to the corporate boundary to the city; thence easterly
and southerly along said city boundary to the centerline of U.S. Interstate 80;
thence southwesterly along said interstate centerline to the point of
beginning;
   (D)   Beginning at the intersection of College Drive and the centerline of
U.S. Interstate 80; thence northeasterly along said interstate centerline to
the Reliance spur track of the Union Pacific Railroad; thence southerly
approximately 0.9 miles along said spur track to an overhead high-voltage
powerline; thence southwesterly along said powerline to College Drive; thence
northwesterly along College Drive to the point of beginning; and
   (E)   Beginning at the intersection of the Reliance spur track of the Union
Pacific Railroad and the corporate boundary of the city; thence southerly along
said track to Stagecoach Boulevard; thence southwesterly along Stagecoach
Boulevard to Foothill Boulevard; thence northerly along Foothill Boulevard to
the crossing of the buried water pipeline serving the Jim Bridger Power Plant;
thence southwesterly along said buried pipeline to the westerly boundary of the
corporate limits to the city; thence beginning northerly and continuing along
said corporate boundary to the point of beginning.
(Prior Code, § 1-304) (Ord. 1351, passed - -; Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963,
passed - -; Ord. 177, passed 9-22-1919; Ord. 76-21, passed 6-15-1976; Ord. 92-
13, passed 5-5-1992)
§ 11.05 FOURTH WARD.
   The Fourth Ward shall include all of that all that area lying within the
city, being more particularly described as follows:
   (A)   Beginning at the intersection of C Street and Union Pacific Railroad
mainline track; thence northeasterly along said mainline track to the Broadway
Street underpass; thence southwesterly along said Broadway Street to F Street;
thence southeasterly along F Street to Second Street; thence northeasterly
along Second Street to Edgar Street; thence easterly along Edgar Street to Gale
Street; thence southerly along Gale Street to Lee Street; thence easterly along
Lee Street to Angle Street; thence southeasterly along Angle Street to Q
Street; thence southerly along Q Street to Thorpe Street; thence westerly along
Thorpe Street to G Street; thence southeasterly and southerly along G Street
and Connecticut Avenue to D Street; thence westerly along D Street to Reed
Street; thence southerly and southwesterly along Reed Street to C Street;
thence northwesterly along C Street to the point of beginning;
   (B)   Beginning at the intersection of the mainline track of the Union
Pacific Railroad and the Southside Belt Route; thence southeasterly along said
belt route to the easterly projection of Edgar Street; thence westerly along
said projection and Edgar Street to Collins Street; thence southerly along
Collins Street to the northerly projection of Garnet Street; thence southerly
along said projection and southwesterly along Garnet Street to Agate Street;
thence southeasterly along Agate Street to Sapphire Street; thence
southwesterly along Sapphire Street to Carson Street; thence northwesterly
along Carson Street to Emerald Street; thence southwesterly and westerly along
Emerald Street to Fremont Street; thence southwesterly along Fremont Street and
the projection thereof to the former Mountain Fuel Railroad spur grade; thence
southeasterly along said railroad grade to the Southside Belt Route; thence
southwesterly along said belt route to New Hampshire Street; thence
northwesterly along New Hampshire Street to Pennsylvania Avenue; thence
northerly and westerly along Pennsylvania Avenue to Connecticut Avenue; thence
northerly along Connecticut Avenue and northwesterly along G Street to Thorpe
Street; thence easterly along Thorpe Street to Q Street; thence northerly along
Q Street to Angle Street; thence northwesterly along Angle Street to Lee
Street; thence westerly along Lee Street to Gale Street; thence northerly along
Gale Street to Edgar Street; thence northwesterly along Edgar Street to Second
Street; thence southwesterly along Second Street to F Street; thence
northwesterly along F Street to Broadway Street; thence northeasterly and
northerly along Broadway Street to the M Street underpass and the mainline
track Union Pacific Railroad; thence northeasterly and easterly along said
mainline track to the point of beginning;
   (C)   Beginning at the intersection of State Highway 430 and the corporate
boundary of the city; thence northwesterly along said highway to the Southside
Belt Route underpass; thence northeasterly approximately 500 feet along said
belt route to the former Mountain Fuel Railroad spur grade; thence
northwesterly along said railroad grade to the southwesterly projection of
Fremont Avenue; thence northeasterly along said projection and Fremont Avenue
to Emerald Street; thence easterly and northeasterly along Emerald Street to
Carson Street; thence southeasterly along Carson Street to Sapphire Street;
thence northeasterly along Sapphire Street to Agate Street; thence
northwesterly along Agate Street to Garnet Street; thence northeasterly along
Garnet Street and the northerly projection thereof to Collins Street; thence
northerly along Collins Street to Edgar Street; thence easterly along Edgar
Street and the easterly projection thereof to the Southside Belt Route; thence
northwesterly and northerly along said belt route to Ninth Street; thence
southeasterly along Ninth Street to Swanson Drive; thence northeasterly along
Swanson Drive to the centerline of U.S. Interstate 80; thence northwesterly
along said interstate centerline to the corporate boundary of the city; thence
beginning easterly and continuing along said corporate boundary to the point of
beginning;
   (D)   Beginning at the intersection of Center Street and the Reliance spur
track of the Union Pacific Railroad; thence easterly and northeasterly along
Center Street, Bridger Avenue and Pilot Butte Avenue to the crossing of Bitter
Creek; thence easterly along Bitter Creek to the confluence with the Pearl
Street Diversion Canal; southerly and southwesterly along said diversion canal
to the Union Pacific Railroad mainline track; thence southwesterly along said
mainline track to the junction of the Reliance spur track of said railroad;
thence northerly along said spur track to the point of beginning; and
   (E)   Beginning at the junction of the State Highway 430 and Marchant
Street; thence southwesterly and westerly along Marchant Street to Adams
Avenue; thence southerly along Adams Avenue to Fancher Street; thence westerly
along Fancher Street to Lincoln Avenue; thence northerly along Lincoln Avenue
to Marchant Street; thence westerly along Marchant Street to the easterly fence
line of the Rock Springs Municipal Cemetery; thence northerly along said fence
line to Thompson Street; thence westerly along Thompson Street to Washington
Avenue; thence northeasterly and northerly along Washington Avenue to Wyoming
Street; thence westerly along Wyoming Street to Massachusetts Avenue; thence
northerly along Massachusetts Avenue to D Street; thence easterly along D
Street to Pennsylvania Avenue; thence southerly along Pennsylvania Avenue to
New Hampshire Street; thence southeasterly along New Hampshire Street and State
Highway 430 to the point of beginning.
(Prior Code, § 1-305) (Ord. 1351, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 76-
21, passed 6-15-1976; Ord. 92-13, passed 5-5-1992)
§ 11.06 SEAL OF THE CITY.
   The seal of the City of Rock Springs, Wyoming, shall be as follows: in the
center the word “Incorporated” and the figures “1888,” and around the outer
edge the words “City of Rock Springs, State of Wyoming,” shall be and the same
is hereby adopted and declared to be the seal of the city.
(Prior Code, § 1-901) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 26,
passed 8-12-1904)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 30.01 ELECTIVE OFFICERS.
   The elective officers of the city shall be the Mayor and two Council members
from each ward, who shall be elected in the manner by law provided.
(Prior Code, § 1-401) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1559,
passed 7-23-1963)
§ 30.02 APPOINTIVE OFFICERS.
   The appointive officers of the city shall be City Attorney, such number of
Assistant City Attorneys as the City Council may authorize, Director of
Department of Finance and Administration, City Clerk, City Treasurer, Municipal
Judge, Alternate Municipal Judges, Fire Chief (subject to competitive testing
through the Civil Service regulations), Director of Engineering and Operations,
Director of Public Services, Director of Parks and Recreation and Chief of
Police. Said officers shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the consent
of the Council. Any officer not appointed or reappointed pursuant to this
section shall have his or her employment with the city terminated at the time
of the vote taken by the City Council on the appointment. In such case, the
Mayor shall appoint, from within the department wherein the vacancy exists, a
person to serve as the appointive officer on an interim basis. This person
shall hold the position for no more than 30 days without prior approval of the
majority of the City Council. Every 30 days thereafter, a majority of the
governing body shall vote to allow the interim position to exist for an
additional 30 days. Within 60 days of the date of the creation of the vacancy,
the Mayor shall make the nomination of a new appointee unless an extension of
this time period is granted by vote of the majority of the governing body. The
terms of the Assistant City Attorneys and Alternate Municipal Judges shall be
at the will of the Mayor.
(Prior Code, § 1-402) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1979,
passed - -; Ord. 9, passed 8-4-1904; Ord. 864, passed 1-7-1946; Ord. 1536,
passed 3-18-1963; Ord. 2115, passed 7-2-1973; Ord. 2159, passed 12-27-1973;
Ord. 2222, passed 7-1-1974; Ord. 2279, passed 12-16-1974; Ord. 76-18, passed 6-
1-1976; Ord. 77-6, passed 4-5-1977; Ord. 77-25, passed 7-19-1977; Ord. 83-3,
passed 3-1-1983; Ord. 85-1, passed 3- -1985; Ord. 87-16, passed 9-2-1987; Ord.
95-04, passed 7-18-1995; Ord. 2013-20, passed 12-17-2013; Ord. 2019-03, passed
3-5-2019)
§ 30.03 VACANCIES; MANNER OF FILLING.
   (A)   A vacancy in the office of the Mayor or Council member exists whenever
any of the following occurs during a Mayor’s or Council member’s term of
office:
      (1)   A failure to fulfill residency requirements as required by §
30.01;
      (2)   A conviction for a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude or
constituting a breach of his or her oath of office; and/or
      (3)   Any other occurrence specified in Wyo. Stat. § 22-18-101(a).
   (B)   (1)   The governing body shall by resolution declare a Mayor’s or
Council member’s office vacant whenever sufficient grounds exist pursuant to
division (A) above.
      (2)   If a vacancy is known to occur at a future date, the governing body
may choose a successor prior to the date of the vacancy, although the successor
shall not be appointed until a vacancy is declared by the governing body.
   (C)   (1)   Council vacancies shall be filled by appointment of the
governing body after the office is declared vacant. The governing body shall
meet within 15 days after declaring an office vacant to appoint a successor.
      (2)   Each member of the governing body may nominate an eligible person
to fill the vacancy. The nominee who receives a majority of the votes shall be
appointed to the vacancy. No vote shall be taken unless all members of the
governing body are present.
      (3)   Once nominations are received, all the members of the governing
body shall vote by open ballot or by voice vote until the two nominees
receiving the greatest number of votes are selected, unless one nominee
receives a majority of the votes during the first ballot. The governing body
shall vote by successive ballots, if necessary, until one of the nominees
receives a majority of the votes.
      (4)   If vacancies are determined to have occurred simultaneously, the
governing body shall establish by resolution the sequence in which the
vacancies are filled.
      (5)   Mayoral vacancies shall be filled from the Council in the same
manner as required for Council vacancies. The President of the governing body
shall occupy the office of the Mayor until the vacancy is filled, pursuant to
Wyo. Stat. § 15-3-204.
(Prior Code, § 1-403) (Ord. 93-11, passed 7-20-1993; Ord. 2023-09, passed 12-5-
2023)
§ 30.04 CITY EMPLOYEES GENERALLY.
   (A)   The governing body of the city shall by ordinance or resolution have
and retain the power as the governing body of the city to set and review the
salaries of all city officers and employees. A majority of the elected members
of the governing body must approve the resolutions approving department head
salaries.
   (B)   The governing body of the city shall, effective July 1, 1989, and
thereafter on or before July 1 of each year, establish by resolution the
salaries of the Clerk, Treasurer, Attorney, Fire Chief, Police Chief, Municipal
Judges, Director of the Department of Finance and Administration, Director of
Engineering and Operations, Director of Public Services, Director of Parks and
Recreation and any other department heads of the city as specified by
ordinance. Said salaries shall be in addition to the employee benefits, such as
health and life insurance, retirement and longevity and other prerogatives and
privileges which shall not be considered as salary. The salaries for the above
described heads of departments shall be issued only in the amounts set by the
governing body and approved by resolution of the governing body.
   (C)   As of the date of the filing of this section, all prior ordinances
and/or resolutions which set forth salary level ranges and/or caps for the
department heads described in division (A) above are hereby repealed.
(Prior Code, § 1-604) (Ord. 82-32, passed 7-6-1982; Ord. 84-14, passed 9- -
1984; Ord. 85-2, passed 3- -1985; Ord. 85-21, passed 10-1-1985; Ord. 87-01,
passed 2-3-1987; Ord. 89-09, passed 2-21-1989; Ord. 89-22, passed 9-19-1989;
Ord. 2014-07, passed 7-1-2014)
§ 30.05 AUTHORITY FOR MUNICIPAL OFFICERS TO ISSUE CITATIONS.
   In accordance with the authority granted to municipalities by the state
legislature in Wyo. Stat. § 7-2-103(e) and Wyo. Stat. § 15-1-103, effective
July 1, 2007, the following employees of the city are hereby granted the
authority to issue municipal citations for the limited purpose of enforcing
city ordinances related to animal control, parking and the municipal code:
   (A)   Animal Control Officer;
   (B)   Animal Control Assistant;
   (C)   Detention/Community Officer;
   (D)   Parking and Nuisance Control Officer;
   (E)   Building Inspector;
   (F)   Plans Examiner;
   (G)   Electrical Inspector; and
   (H)   Fire Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 2-300)
POWERS AND DUTIES OF OFFICERS
§ 30.20 COUNCIL MEMBERS.
   A majority of the members elected to the governing body shall constitute a
quorum for the transaction of any business of the city, but a less number may
adjourn, from time to time, and compel the attendance of absent members. The
Council may elect one of its body, who shall be styled the “President of the
Council,” who shall preside at all meetings of the Council in the absence of
the Mayor, and in the absence of the President of the Council, the Council may
elect one of its own body to occupy the Mayor’s place temporarily, who shall be
styled “Acting President of the Council,” and the President and Acting
President, when occupying the place of the Mayor, shall have the same
privileges as other members of the Council, and all acts of the President or
Acting President, while so acting, shall be as binding upon the Council and
upon the city, as if done by the Mayor.
(Prior Code, § 1-502) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 2013-
21, passed 12-17-2013)
§ 30.21 CITY ATTORNEY.
   (A)   Bond and duties.
      (1)   Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, he or she
shall execute to the city a bond in the sum of $5,000.
      (2)   The City Attorney shall be the legal advisor of the Council and
city officers; he or she shall commence, prosecute and defend all suits and
actions necessary to be commenced, prosecuted or defended on behalf of the
city, or that may be ordered by the Council, and shall attend meetings of the
Council, and give his or her opinion upon any matter submitted to him or her,
either orally or in writing, as may be required. He or she shall draft all
ordinances, contracts and other instruments necessary to conduct regular city
business. He or she shall do all other things provided for by ordinances or
required by law.
(Prior Code, § 1-503)
   (B)   Assistant City Attorney. The Assistant City Attorneys shall perform
such duties as designated by the Mayor and the City Attorney jointly.
(Prior Code, § 1-503.1)
(Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1979, passed - -; Ord. 5,
passed 8-4-1904; Ord. 2115, passed 7-2-1973; Ord. 77-25, passed 7-19-1977; Ord.
2013-21, passed 12-17-2013)
§ 30.22 CITY CLERK.
   (A)   Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the City Clerk
shall execute to city a bond in the sum of $1,000.
   (B)   He or she shall have the custody of all laws and ordinances, shall
attend the sittings of the City Council and shall keep a correct journal of the
proceedings of the Council, which journal, after the approval of each sitting
of the City Council, shall be signed by the Mayor and attested by the Clerk. He
or she shall keep a record of all outstanding bonds against the city, showing
the number and amount of each, and for and to whom said bonds were issued, and
when any bonds are purchased, or paid, or cancelled, said record shall show the
fact, and in his or her annual report, he or she shall describe particularly
the bonds issued and sold during the year, and the terms of sale, with each and
every item of expense thereof. He or she shall attest all orders and drafts
upon the Treasurer and affix thereto the Seal of the City, and keep an accurate
record thereof in a book provided for that purpose. He or she shall make at the
end of each month a report showing the amount appropriated to each fund, and
the whole amount of warrants drawn thereon, which shall be spread at large upon
the records, and at the end of each year, a report embracing a summary of such
monthly reports. He or she shall keep the Corporate Seal, papers and books
belonging to said city. He or she shall attest and affix the Corporate Seal to
all bonds and licenses, issued in pursuance of the orders of the City Council
and the ordinances of the city. He or she shall issue requisitions to the
various officers and employees of the city, authorizing the purchase of
supplies, repairs and equipment incidental and necessary in the ordinary course
of city business; provided, however, that he or she shall issue no requisition
for supplies, repairs and equipment not incidental and necessary in the
ordinary course of city business without first having obtained express
authorization from the Mayor and City Council. He or she shall keep and care
for all public records and shall act as the designated public records person
for responding to requests for such records. He or she shall also perform such
other duties as may be required by the ordinances of the city.
(Prior Code, § 1-504) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 4,
passed 8-4-1904; Ord. 2019-13, passed 6-18-2019)
§ 30.23 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (A)   Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the Chief of
Police shall execute to the city a bond in the sum of $5,000.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to attend all meetings of
the Council. The Chief of Police shall perform the duties incumbent upon such
office and shall have the immediate superintendence of the Police Department.
(Prior Code, § 1-506) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 4,
passed 8-4-1904; Ord. 94-31, passed 9-18-1998)
§ 30.24 MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   (A)   Bond and duties.
      (1)   Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, he or she
shall execute to the city a bond in the sum of $5,000.
      (2)   It shall be his or her duty to hear and determine all offenses
against the ordinances of the city, arising within the limits of the city. The
Municipal Judge shall be a conservator of the peace, and his or her court shall
be open every day except weekends and legal holidays, to hear and determine all
cases cognizable before him or her. No act shall be performed by him or her on
weekends and legal holidays, except to receive complaints, issue process and
take bail and file such reports.
      (3)   He or she shall file such reports as may be required by the City
Clerk, and he or she shall perform such other duties as may be required of him
or her by the ordinances of the city, provided they do not conflict with the
laws of the state or the laws of the United States of America. In case a
Municipal Judge is absent temporarily or unable to perform the duties of his or
her office, the Mayor may appoint a suitable person to act as Municipal Judge
during his or her absence or disability.
(Prior Code, § 1-507)
   (B)   Alternate Municipal Judge.
      (1)   The Alternate Municipal Judge shall act only in the absence or
disqualification of the Municipal Judge.
      (2)   The Alternate Municipal Judge, when on duty, shall perform all of
the duties of the regular Municipal Judge.
(Prior Code, § 1-507.1)
(Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1982, passed - -; Ord. 52,
passed 8-18-1904; Ord. 132, passed 3-15-1915; Ord. 2115, passed 7-2-1973; Ord.
87-17, passed 9-2-1987; Ord. 87-18, passed 9-2-1987; Ord. 2013-21, passed 12-
17-2013)
§ 30.25 FIRE CHIEF.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall have charge of the Fire Department of
the city. He or she shall have control and command of all property belonging to
the Department; he or she shall superintend and direct the acts and doings of
the firefighters, and shall prescribe such rules and regulations as may be
necessary, subject to the approval of the Council. He or she shall see that the
ordinances of this city with reference to the Fire Department are faithfully
observed. He or she shall have command at all fires over all officers and
persons who may be present and shall take all proper measures for the
extinguishment of fires, protection of life and property and the preservation
of law and order. He or she shall report quarterly, in writing, the fires
occurring during that quarter and doings of the Fire Department, and make all
suggestions and recommendations he or she deems proper. He or she shall perform
such other duties as may be required of him or her by the ordinances of the
city.
(Prior Code, § 1-508) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -)
§ 30.26 DIRECTOR OF ENGINEERING AND OPERATIONS.
   (A)   The Director of Engineering and Operations shall, when requested by
the City Council or Mayor, make all surveys, estimates, maps and profiles
required for any city work or improvement.
   (B)   The Director of Engineering and Operations shall also assist other
departments when a problem or questions arise which requires engineering
expertise.
   (C)   The Director of Engineering and Operations shall keep records showing
the official grades of all streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters and the
location of all connections therewith, and of all fire hydrants and of all
valves in water mains. The Director of Engineering and Operations shall keep
any other records the governing body requires and turn all papers, records,
books and maps over to his or her successor as required under Wyo. Stat. § 15-
3-212.
   (D)   The Director of Engineering and Operations shall have supervisory
authority over any subordinate engineers and shall all have supervisory
authority over the operation and maintenance of the city streets, the Water
Department and the Cemetery.
(Prior Code, § 1-509) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 99-
03, passed 2-2-1999)
§ 30.27 CITY PLANNER.
   The City Planner shall perform such duties as designated and directed by the
Mayor and the Director of Public Services.
(Prior Code, § 1-515) (Ord. 2222, passed 7-1-1974; Ord. 99-03, passed 2-2-1999)
§ 30.28 DIRECTOR OF THE DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE ADMINISTRATION.
   The Director of the Department of Finance Administration shall direct and
control the budgetary, planning and operational activities of the Department
and shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required of him or
her by the Mayor or the ordinances of the city.
(Prior Code, § 1-517) (Ord. 2159, passed 12-27-1973)
§ 30.29 DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICES.
   The Director of Public Services shall direct and control the budgetary,
planning and operational activities of the Department of Public Services and
shall perform such other duties directed by the Mayor. The Director of Public
Services shall supervise the operations and activities of the wastewater
treatment plant, the personnel who perform various inspections, the Planning
and Zoning Department and the maintenance of city vehicles.
(Prior Code, § 1-518) (Ord. 2159, passed 12-27-1973; Ord. 99-03, passed 2-2-
1999)
§ 30.30 DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SAFETY.
   The Director of Public Safety shall be in general charge of public safety as
designated by the Mayor, which duties may include general supervision of the
Police Department and the Fire Department.
(Prior Code, § 1-519) (Ord. 77-6, passed 4-5-1977)
§ 30.31 DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION.
   The Director of Parks and Recreation shall direct and control the budgetary,
planning and operational activities of the Department and shall perform such
other duties and functions as may be required of him or her by the Mayor or the
ordinances of the city.
(Prior Code, § 1-520) (Ord. 85-3, passed 3- -1985)
§ 30.32 CITY INSPECTOR.
   (A)   Office created. There is hereby created the office of City Inspector.
The City Inspector shall be ex-officio Fire Inspector of all new or renovated
infrastructure, development and buildings, Building Inspector, Electrical
Inspector, Gas Inspector, Sewer Inspector and Mechanical Inspector, unless some
other person is designated by the Mayor and City Council to act in any of said
several capacities.
(Prior Code, § 7-501)
   (B)   Duties. Unless otherwise provided, the City Inspector shall fulfill
the duties of inspector as specifically set forth in the Building Code,
Electrical Code, Gas Code, Mechanical Code and Plumbing and Sewer Code,
respectively. He or she shall also keep the records as provided for in said
Codes.
(Prior Code, § 7-502)
   (C)   Powers. The City Inspector shall have the powers as set forth in the
Building Code, Electrical Code, Gas Code, Mechanical Code, Fire Code for new
development, infrastructure and buildings and Plumbing and Sewer Code,
respectively.
(Prior Code, § 7-503)
(Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 2011-03, passed 4-5-2011;
Ord. 2013-18, passed 11-5-2013)
COMPENSATION
§ 30.45 MAYOR.
   (A)   The Mayor shall receive an annual salary not to exceed $24,000, plus
not to exceed $3,000 per year in employee benefits, including hospital and
pension benefits other than Social Security benefits, to be authorized from
time to time.
   (B)   The Mayor has the option to accept the cash value of the hospital and
pension benefits in lieu of the benefits themselves.
   (C)   Said salary and benefit increase shall be effective at the conclusion
of the term of office of the Mayor.
(Prior Code, § 1-601) (Ord. 787, passed - -; Ord. 825, passed - -; Ord. 927,
passed - -; Ord. 1081, passed - -; Ord. 1118, passed - -; Ord. 1222, passed -
-; Ord. 1368, passed - -; Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord.
1578, passed 12-16-1963; Ord. 1709, passed 12-19-1966; Ord. 1907, passed 12-2-
1970; Ord. 2281, passed 12-16-1974; Ord. 91-19, passed 12-3-1991; Ord. 2013-19,
passed 12-3-2013)
§ 30.46 COUNCIL MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Council members shall receive an annual salary of $12,000, plus
not to exceed $3,000 per year in employee benefits, including hospital and
pension benefits other than Social Security benefits, to be authorized from
time to time.
   (B)   Each Council member has the option to accept the cash value of the
hospital and pension benefits in lieu of the benefits themselves.
   (C)   Said salary and benefit increase shall be effective at the conclusion
of the term of office for each Council member.
(Prior Code, § 1-602) (Ord. 787, passed - -; Ord. 825, passed - -; Ord. 927,
passed - -; Ord. 1081, passed - -; Ord. 1118, passed - -; Ord. 1222, passed -
-; Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1578, passed 12-16-1963;
Ord. 1709, passed 12-19-1966; Ord. 1907, passed 12-2-1970; Ord. 2281, passed
12-16-1974; Ord. 91-19, passed 12-3-1991; Ord. 2013-19, passed 12-3-2013)
§ 30.47 ALTERNATE MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   The Alternate Municipal Judge shall be paid in an amount as set forth by
resolution, pursuant to the provisions of §
30.04.
(Prior Code, § 1-605) (Ord. 81-28, passed 6-16-1981; Ord. 87-19, passed 9-2-
1987; Ord. 2014-07, passed 7-1-2014)
CHAPTER 31: COUNCIL MEETINGS
Section
   
31.01   Regular Council meetings
   
31.02   Order of business
   
31.03   Rules
   
31.04   Committees
§ 31.01 REGULAR COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   The regular meeting of the City Council shall be held in the Council
chambers in the City Hall in said city on the first and third Tuesday in each
month at the hour of 7:00 p.m. In the event that any regular meeting day of the
Council falls on a legal holiday, the meeting shall be postponed until the next
succeeding business day, at the same time and place. In the event of an
emergency, or upon such other special or unforeseen circumstances as the Mayor
may, in the Mayor’s sole discretion, deem expedient or appropriate, a regular
meeting of the Council may likewise be postponed until the next succeeding
business day, or as soon thereafter as the Mayor may direct, at the same time
and place.
(Prior Code, § 1-701) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1,
passed 7-21-1904; Ord. 1970, passed 11-15-1971; Ord. 2282, passed 12-16-1974;
Ord. 2017-01, passed 6-6-2017)
§ 31.02 ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   At the hour appointed by the Council, meetings shall be called to order by
the Mayor, or in the Mayor’s absence, by the President of the Council, or in
the absence of both, by the Clerk, in which latter case some member of the
Council shall then be elected to act as Chairperson temporarily who shall be
styled “Acting President of the Council,” and after the roll is called by the
Clerk, if a quorum be present, the Council shall proceed to the business before
it, in order, following:
   (A)   Reading of the minutes of the last meeting and amendment and approval
of the same;
   (B)   Presentation of petitions and reports of officers;
   (C)   Reports of standing committees;
   (D)   Reports of special committees;
   (E)   Communications to the Council;
   (F)   Presentation of bills and claims;
   (G)   Unfinished business of preceding meeting; and
   (H)   Miscellaneous business, motions, resolution, notices and the like.
(Prior Code, § 1-703) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -)
§ 31.03 RULES.
   (A)   Rule I. The rules of the procedure and order of business shall be
strictly adhered to by the Council unless they shall be temporarily suspended
by a two-thirds vote of the members present.
   (B)   Rule II. When the Council is in executive session, the Council
chambers or place of meeting shall be cleared of all persons excepting the
Mayor and Council members, and such members of the city government as may be
requested to remain by the Council, and, if required, a record of the meeting
shall be made and kept the same as when the Council is in open session.
   (C)   Rule III. At all meetings of the Council, a majority of all the
Council members shall constitute a quorum for doing business, but a minority
may adjourn from day to day and compel the attendance of absent members by a
fine of not exceeding $10 for each offense, and, when required, the Marshal or
any Deputy Marshal shall have the power to summon and bring the absent members
to the Council.
   (D)   Rule IV. The Mayor, or Presiding Officer, in the absence of the Mayor,
shall preserve order and decorum and shall decide questions of order, subject
to an appeal to the Council.
   (E)   Rule V. While the Mayor is putting the question, no Council member
shall walk across or out of the Council chambers or place of meeting.
   (F)   Rule VI. Every member, before speaking on any question, shall address
the Mayor or proper Chair by his or her proper title, but shall not proceed
with any remarks until recognized and named by the Chair.
   (G)   Rule VII. No Council member shall speak more than twice to the same
general question, nor more than once to a previous question, without leave of
two-thirds of the members of the Council, nor more than once in any case until
every member choosing to speak shall have spoken.
   (H)   Rule VIII. While a member of the Council is speaking, no member shall
entertain private conversation.
   (I)   Rule IX. A member called to order shall immediately suspend his or her
remarks unless permitted to explain. If there is no appeal, the decision of the
Chair shall be conclusive, but if the member shall appeal to the Council, the
Council shall decide the case without debate.
   (J)   Rule X. Motions upon the subject under consideration shall have
precedence in the following order:
      (1)   To lay on the table;
      (2)   To postpone;
      (3)   To commit; and
      (4)   To amend.
   (K)   Rule XI. All motions shall be reduced to writing, if required by the
Chair or any member of the Council, and when stated by the Chair shall be open
for consideration, and all resolutions must be written and shall be open for
consideration after being read by the Chair, and no motion or resolution can be
withdrawn after it shall have been amended or decided.
   (L)   Rule XII. A motion for a “previous question” shall preclude all
amendments and debate on the main question until the motion for the previous
question is decided, and a motion to postpone it to a day certain shall, until
it is decided, preclude all amendments to the first question.
   (M)   Rule XIII. The previous question shall be put in this form: “Shall the
main question be now put?” and effect when sustained by the majority of the
members present, shall be to put an end to all debate and bring the governing
body to vote on the question or questions before it.
   (N)   Rule XIV. On the question of the passage of any ordinance, bylaw or
resolution, the ayes and nays shall be taken and a record made of the same, and
on all other questions, the ayes and nays shall be taken when called for by any
member.
   (O)   Rule XV. A motion to adjourn the Council shall always be in order,
except:
      (1)   When a member is in possession of the floor;
      (2)   While the ayes and nays are being called;
      (3)   When the Council is voting;
      (4)   When adjournment was the last preceding motion; and
      (5)   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
   (P)   Rule XVI. If the question before the Council shall contain two or more
distinct propositions, any member may have the same divided on request.
   (Q)   Rule XVII. The Council shall keep a journal of its proceedings, which
shall be open at all times for inspection and shall be kept by the City Clerk.
   (R)   Rule XVIII. When a blank is to be filled and different sums and times
proposed, the question shall first be put upon the largest sum and longest
time.
   (S)   Rule XIX. All questions relating to the priority of business shall be
decided without debate.
   (T)   Rule XX.
      (1)   Each member of the governing body who shall be present when a
question is to be voted upon shall vote thereon, unless:
         (a)   He or she is excused therefrom by the Council;
         (b)   He or she is directly interested in the question from a personal
standpoint; or
         (c)   He or she is on trial.
      (2)   In the event a member of the governing body who is present
abstains, or otherwise fails to vote, unless excused as aforesaid, his or her
abstention or failure to vote shall be considered as acquiescing in the result
of the majority of those who do vote, and he or she shall be considered to have
voted with the majority. If any member of the governing body is excused as set
forth above, that member shall remove himself or herself from the Council
chambers for the discussion on the question and be treated as being absent for
the purposes of counting votes on the question. Passage of an ordinance shall
require the affirmative vote of the majority of the qualified members of the
entire governing body.
   (U)   Rule XXI. These rules may be amended at any meeting of the governing
body by a vote of two-thirds of the members present, the same being presented
in writing and read and the ayes and nays shall be called as in the passage of
ordinances.
   (V)   Rule XXII. The most current version of Robert’s Rules of Order as
published by the Robert’s Rules Association and Parliamentary Law at a Glance,
by E. C. Utter, based on Robert’s Rules of Order Revised, shall be the standard
authority upon all parliamentary questions which may arise before the Council,
which are not otherwise provided for in this code of rules and regulations. The
exception to the authority of Robert’s Rules of Order Revised shall be the
minutes which shall be prepared according to the Handbook for State Municipal
Clerks and Treasurers.
(Prior Code, § 1-704) (Ord. 81-38, passed 11-3-1981; Ord. 87-31, passed 1-19-
1988; Ord. 89-02, passed 2-21-1989; Ord. 22-09, passed 6-21-2022)
§ 31.04 COMMITTEES.
   (A)   Standing committees.
      (1)   The standing committees shall be appointed annually, and the
persons first named on the committee shall be Chairperson thereof. The
following shall be the standing committees:
         (a)   Finance and Budget Committee;
         (b)   Street and Alleys Committee;
         (c)   Police Department Committee;
         (d)   Fire Department Committee; and
         (e)   City Buildings Committee.
      (2)   The standing committees of the Council shall consist of not less
than two members each.
   (B)   Special committees. Special committees shall be appointed by the Mayor
or, in his or her absence, by the President of the Council or, in the absence
of both, the “Acting President of the Council,” unless otherwise ordered, in
which case they may be appointed as the Council may direct.
   (C)   Reports. All committees shall in all cases report in writing, all
reports of committees shall be addressed to the Mayor and City Council.
(Prior Code, § 1-707) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1781,
passed 1-6-1969; Ord. 97-03, passed 5-6-1997; Ord. 2025-04, passed 2-18-2025)
CHAPTER 32: ORGANIZATIONS
Section
   
32.01   Departments generally
   
32.02   Department of Engineering and Operations
   
32.03   Department of Finance and Administration
   
32.04   Department of Public Services
   
32.05   Department of Parks and Recreation
   
32.06   Department of City Attorney
   
32.07   Department of Municipal Court
§ 32.01 DEPARTMENTS GENERALLY.
   There are hereby created the following departments of city government, which
departments shall have the functions, powers and duties as set forth
hereinafter and which shall operate subject to the direction and control of the
Mayor and City Council:
   (A)   Department of Engineering and Operations;
   (B)   Department of Finance and Administration;
   (C)   Department of Public Works;
   (D)   Department of Parks and Recreation;
   (E)   Department of City Attorney; and
   (F)   Department of Municipal Court.
(Prior Code, § 1-1101) (Ord. 88-06, passed 3-1-1988; Ord. 99-01, passed 2-2-
1999)
§ 32.02 DEPARTMENT OF ENGINEERING AND OPERATIONS.
   (A)   The Department of Engineering and Operations shall include the
following sub-departments and functions: Engineering, Streets, Water
Department, the Cemetery and the offices of the Director of Engineering and
Operations.
   (B)   The Department of Engineering and Operations shall include the
positions of Engineer I and Engineer II. The position of Engineer II requires a
State Professional Engineer license and a valid driver’s license.
(Prior Code, § 1-1102) (Ord. 2159, passed 12-27-1973; Ord. 99-01, passed 2-2-
1999)
§ 32.03 DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION.
   The Department of Finance and Administration shall include the following
sub-departments and functions:
   (A)   Budget, payroll, personnel, records, licenses, health, purchasing and
the office of the City Clerk and City Treasurer;
   (B)   Meter reading and the financial administration of the water system;
and
   (C)   The Library Board and Airport Board shall be part of the Department of
Finance and Administration.
(Prior Code, § 1-1103) (Ord. 2159, passed 12-27-1973; Ord. 88-06, passed 3-1-
1988)
§ 32.04 DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICES.
   The Department of Public Services shall include the following sub-
departments and functions: Planning and Zoning, Vehicle Maintenance,
Inspections and Waste Water Treatment.
(Prior Code, § 1-1104) (Ord. 2159, passed 12-27-1973; Ord. 88-06, passed 3-1-
1988; Ord. 99-01, passed 2-2-1999)
§ 32.05 DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION.
   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall include the following sub-
departments and functions:
   (A)   Parks, the golf course, the Family Recreation Center and the Civic
Center and the Recreation Department; and
   (B)   The Recreation Board shall be part of the Department of Parks and
Recreation.
(Prior Code, § 1-1105) (Ord. 88-06, passed 3-1-1988)
§ 32.06 DEPARTMENT OF CITY ATTORNEY.
   The Department of City Attorney shall include the following sub-departments
and functions:
   (A)   Assistant City Attorney; and
   (B)   Drafting all ordinances, contracts and other instruments, legal
advisor of the Council and city officers, handle litigation involving the city
and the office of the City Attorney.
(Prior Code, § 1-1106) (Ord. 88-06, passed 3-1-1988)
§ 32.07 DEPARTMENT OF MUNICIPAL COURT.
   The Department of Municipal Court shall include the following sub-
departments and functions:
   (A)   Alternate Municipal Judge; and
   (B)   Municipal Court, fines and the office of the Municipal Judge.
(Prior Code, § 1-1107) (Ord. 88-06, passed 3-1-1988)
CHAPTER 33: MUNICIPAL COURT
Section
   
33.01   Municipal Court
   
33.02   Exclusive jurisdiction
   
33.03   Complaint
   
33.04   Defect in form of complaint not fatal
   
33.05   Warrant for arrest
   
33.06   Arrest without warrant
   
33.07   Person arrested may give bail
   
33.08   Failure of defendant to appear
   
33.09   Commitment when party cannot be tried
   
33.10   Trial
   
33.11   Witnesses
   
33.12   Rendition of judgment
   
33.13   Labor on streets by convicted persons
   
33.14   Malicious prosecution
   
33.15   Appeal
   
33.16   General laws shall govern
   
33.17   Application of city ordinances at airport
   
33.18   Jurisdiction to enforce ordinances within five miles
   
33.19   Jurisdiction to enforce ordinances within one-half mile
   
33.20   Police Justice; power and jurisdiction
   
33.21   Intent
   
33.22   Severability
§ 33.01 MUNICIPAL COURT.
   Whenever in this chapter or any ordinance of the city reference is made to
“Police Court” or “Police Justice,” such court or justice shall hereafter be
referred to as “Municipal Court” and “Municipal Judge.”
(Prior Code, § 2-100) (Ord. 89-30, passed 12-5-1989)
§ 33.02 EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION.
   The Police Justice shall have the power and jurisdiction as provided by the
laws of the state for police justices of municipal courts, and it shall be his
or her duty to try, hear and determine all cases arising under the ordinances
of the city and all complaints for the violation of said ordinances. He or she
shall hold court each day, except Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, for
the trial of such cases and the transaction of such business as may properly
come before him or her. He or she shall hold court at such regular hours as he
or she may designate and at such other times as may be necessary. No act shall
be performed by him or her on Saturdays, Sundays or legal holidays, except to
receive complaints, issue process and take bail. He or she shall have power to
enforce due obedience to all orders, rules and judgments made by him or her; to
issue warrants, subpoenas and other process that may be necessary for the
attendance of witnesses; and he or she may fine or imprison any person for
contempt offered to him or her while holding court, or to process issued by him
or her, in the same manner and to the same extent as the District Court. No
change of venue shall be granted in any case.
(Prior Code, § 2-101) (Ord. 80-25, passed 6-3-1980)
§ 33.03 COMPLAINT.
   Actions for violations of ordinances of this city may be commenced by filing
with the Police Justice a complaint under oath, made by the City Attorney, any
member of the Police Department or any responsible person, stating the nature
of the offense, which complaint may be in the following form.
 
   IN POLICE JUSTICE COURT
STATE OF WYOMING,   )
County of Sweetwater,   ) ss.
City of Rock Springs   )
Police Justice
CITY OF ROCK SPRINGS, Plaintiff, vs. COMPLAINT
                                     Defendant.
   I,                                 , do solemnly swear that on or about the          day of                 , A.D. 20                                     in the City of Rock Springs, county and state aforesaid
the said                                     did then and there unlawfully                                                                                                             contrary to the form of Section
No.                 , of Ordinance No.                                     , of said City in such case made and provided, and against the peace and dignity of said city.
                                           Complainant
Subscribed and sworn to before me                  day of                          , A.D. 20             
                                     Police Justice
 
 
   RECORD OF PROCEEDINGS

Court; stated that his or her name was correctly shown; the nature and penalty of the crime was explained; and he or she was
