actions is as follows. Any person who knowingly makes any false statements,
representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or
other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this chapter, or
by any permit, rule or order issued under it, or who falsifies, tampers with or
knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required to be
maintained by this chapter shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $10,000,
or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both.
(Prior Code, § 7-420) (Ord. 2013-15, passed 10-1-2013; Ord. 2015-02, passed 4-
7-2015)
CHAPTER 55: GAS CODE
Section
   
55.01   Gas Inspector
   
55.02   Application for permit
   
55.03   Notice of time of inspection
   
55.04   When gas to be furnished
   
55.05   Unlawful to tap main supply line
   
55.06   Warning after shut-off
 
   
55.99   Penalty
§ 55.01 GAS INSPECTOR.
   There is hereby created the office of Gas Inspector to be conducted under
the supervision of the City Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 7-301) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 221,
passed 6-23-1924)
§ 55.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to begin any
job of gas fitting until the person so doing has secured from the City Gas
Inspector a permit to do said work. In order to secure said permit, the gas
fitter shall make application, upon blanks furnished for that purpose, to the
City Gas Inspector, and shall notify the City Gas Inspector when the work is
ready for inspection.
   (B)   Said application shall show the name of the owner or agent of the
premises; the lot, block and addition; the name of the gas fitter having charge
of the work; also a description of the work to be done, setting forth the
number and kind of fixtures already installed and to be installed.
(Prior Code, § 7-302) (Ord. 81-44, passed 1-6-1981) Penalty, see §
55.99
§ 55.03 NOTICE OF TIME OF INSPECTION.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of any person, firm or corporation installing any
gas work to notify the Gas Inspector 24 hours in advance of when the work is
ready to be tested or inspected.
   (B)   Said notice must be filed in the office of the Gas Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 7-303) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 221,
passed 6-23-1924; Ord. 2012-10, passed 12-18-2012)
§ 55.04 WHEN GAS TO BE FURNISHED.
   Before any gas may be turned on to any consumer by any gas company, a
certificate must be filed by the Gas Inspector with said company, stating that
this particular work has passed inspection.
(Prior Code, § 7-304) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 221,
passed 6-23-1924)
§ 55.05 UNLAWFUL TO TAP MAIN SUPPLY LINE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, persons or corporation other than the
company furnishing gas, or its duly authorized agent, to tap the main supply
lines furnishing the gas to the inhabitants thereof, which said lines run
through the alleys or streets of the city, or its additions or vicinity; and in
all cases where installations are required or ordered, said gas company, or its
duly authorized agent, shall tap the main and extend the service line to the
property line; and if service lines are installed inside the property line by
other persons than the company furnishing gas or its employees, all of said
installations of service pipe shall be left uncovered until inspection thereof
has been made, and no plumber or gas fitter or other person shall bury any of
said pipes inside the property line until an inspection thereof has been made
and filed with said gas company.
(Prior Code, § 7-306) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 221,
passed 6-23-1924) Penalty, see §
55.99
§ 55.06 WARNING AFTER SHUT-OFF.
   No person, firm or individual shall resume service or turn gas into mains
which have been shut off temporarily or for any length of time until all
consumers using gas from such mains have been notified of the resumption of
service and have been warned to close all outlets left open when the service
was interrupted.
(Prior Code, § 7-307) (Ord. 35-7, passed - -; Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963,
passed - -)
§ 55.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in any sum
not more than $100, to which may be added the costs at the discretion of the
court.
(Prior Code, § 7-308) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 221,
passed 6-23-1924)

CHAPTER 70: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
Section

70.02   Snowmobiles prohibited
   
70.03   Speed limits
   
70.04   Careless driving

70.06   Use of engine compression brakes prohibited
   
70.07   Regulation of cell phones in vehicles
   
70.08   Vehicle registration and liability coverage
   
70.09   Child safety restraint and safety belt usage

§ 70.01 STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED.
   (A)   The city, by this reference, adopts the following provisions of the
State Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways: Wyo. Stat. §§ 31-5-101
through 31-5-110; 31-5-112 through 31-5-225(a); 31-5-226 through 31-5-233(g);
31-5-233(j) through 31-5-233(k); 31-5-301 through 31-5-406; 31-5-503 through
31-5-970; 31-5-1102 through 31-5-1112; 31-5-1201(a) and (c); and 31-5-1202
through 31-5-1214, along with any future amendments thereto.
   (B)   A copy of the “Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways” as herein
adopted by reference shall be placed on file in the office of the City Clerk
and made available for public inspection.
(Prior Code, § 5-201) (Ord. 89-31, passed 12-5-1989; Ord. 01-13, passed 1-15-
2002; Ord. 2010-12, passed 1-4-2011)
§ 70.02 SNOWMOBILES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile in or upon any
streets, alleys, sidewalks, parking lots, parks, railroad and utility rights-
of-way or any other public lands or rights-of-way within the city.
(Prior Code, § 5-202) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.03 SPEED LIMITS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle on the streets,
highways, alleys or other public rights-of-way in the city at a speed greater
than is reasonable and prudent under the existing circumstances and conditions
and having regard for actual or potential hazards.
   (B)   Except when an actual or potential hazard exists requiring a lower
speed for compliance with division (A) above, the following limits shall be the
maximum lawful speeds, and it shall be unlawful to drive a vehicle on the
streets, highways, alleys or other public rights-of-way in the city in excess
of such maximum limits:
      (1)   Fifteen mph in alleys;
      (2)   Twenty mph when passing school buildings or the grounds thereof or
school crossings between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. on school days or
during other times as posted;
      (3)   Twenty-five mph in all other areas of the city unless otherwise
posted; and
      (4)   As posted on official traffic signs in accordance with other
applicable city ordinances or state laws in areas where circumstances and
conditions warrant a maximum speed greater or less than that otherwise herein
specified for the safe and reasonable flow of traffic.
(Prior Code, § 5-203) (Ord. 83-30, passed 12-20-1983; Ord. 85-6, passed 6- -
1985; Ord. 00-22, passed 11-7-2000; Ord. 2021-12, passed 10-5-2021) Penalty,
see §
70.99
§ 70.04 CARELESS DRIVING.
   Whoever operates a motor vehicle upon any public highway within the city or
upon any public parking area or lot within the city in a manner which is not
consistent with the exercise of due and diligent care normally exercised by a
reasonably prudent person under similar circumstances, and where such operation
of a motor vehicle creates an unreasonable risk of harm to persons or property
within the city, is guilty of careless driving.
(Prior Code, § 5-204) (Ord. 87-27, passed 11-17-1987) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.05 DRIVING WHILE LICENSE CANCELLED, SUSPENDED OR REVOKED.
   (A)   Any person who drives a motor vehicle on a public street or highway
within the city at a time when his or her state driver’s license or privileges
have been cancelled, suspended or revoked by the state or any other
jurisdiction, or at a time when any nonresident operating privilege, license or
permit has been cancelled, suspended or revoked pursuant to the laws of the
state or any other jurisdiction, is guilty of driving while license cancelled,
suspended or revoked.
   (B)   Any evidence that a notice or order from the State Department of
Revenue and Taxation, or the division administering the motor vehicle laws
within said Department, or any similar agency in any other state or
jurisdiction, was mailed to the last known address for the person charged under
division (A) above shall be prima facie proof that the person received the
notice or order five days after the notice or order was mailed. For the purpose
of this section, LAST KNOWN ADDRESS shall mean the address on file with the
State Department of Revenue and Taxation, or the division within said
Department administering the motor vehicle laws, or any similar agency in any
other state or jurisdiction.
(Prior Code, § 5-205) (Ord. 91-18, passed 12-3-1991) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.06 USE OF ENGINE COMPRESSION BRAKES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall operate or use any vehicle engine compression brake within
the corporate limits of the city.
(Prior Code, § 5-206) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.07 REGULATION OF CELL PHONES IN VEHICLES.
   (A)   Except as provided by division (B) below, no person shall operate a
motor vehicle while using a mobile, cellular, analog wireless, digital or
satellite telephone. This prohibition of use includes, but is not limited to,
talking, text messaging, taking photographs or any other use which causes a
driver’s attention to be diverted.
   (B)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
      (1)   Persons using a telephone with a “hands free” device allowing the
driver to talk into and listen to the telephone without the use of hands;
      (2)   In an emergency, persons using a telephone to call 911 or other
similar emergency telephone number; or
      (3)   Persons using a telephone while maintaining a motor vehicle in a
stationary parked position and not in gear. This does not include periods
during which a motor vehicle is stopped at an intersection or other location as
the result of the placement of a traffic control device on a public street or
highway.
(Prior Code, § 5-208) (Ord. 09-11, passed 5-19-2009; Ord. 2021-12, passed 10-5-
2021) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.08 VEHICLE REGISTRATION AND LIABILITY COVERAGE.
   (A)   In accordance with the authority granted to municipalities by the
state legislature in Wyo. Stat. § 31-5-109(a), the city, by this reference,
adopts Wyo. Stat. §§ 31-4-101 and 31-4-103, as amended.
   (B)   A copy of the general offenses and penalties, as herein adopted by
reference, shall be placed on file in the office of the City Clerk and made
available for public inspection.
(Prior Code, § 5-209) (Ord. 2014-08, passed 8-9-2014)
§ 70.09 CHILD SAFETY RESTRAINT AND SAFETY BELT USAGE.
   (A)   In accordance with the authority granted to municipalities by the
state legislature in Wyo. Stat. § 31-5-109(a), the city, by this reference,
adopts Wyo. Stat. §§ 31-5-1301 through 31-5-1305 and §§ 31-5-1401 through 31-5-
1402, as amended.
   (B)   A copy of the regulations of traffic on highways, as herein adopted by
reference, shall be placed on file in the office of the City Clerk and made
available for public inspection.
(Prior Code, § 5-210) (Ord. 2021-16, passed 11-16-2021)
§ 70.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this title for which no specific
penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99.
   (B)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any
duly adopted provision of this title, or any order, rule or regulation lawfully
made or promulgated in accordance therewith, including, but not limited to, the
provisions of the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, as herein adopted
by reference.
      (2)   Any person failing to comply with the provisions of this title, as
herein set forth or later amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $750 unless
another penalty is specifically provided for a particular provision hereof.
Allowable costs may be assessed upon conviction in addition to any fine at the
discretion of the Municipal Judge.
(Prior Code, § 5-101)
   (C)   (1)   Any person who is convicted of speeding under §
70.03, and the violation occurs within a residential zone, shall be punished by
a fine of not less than $50 nor more than $750.
      (2)   For the purpose of this division (C), RESIDENTIAL ZONE shall mean
those areas within the city which have been designated R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-
5 or R-6.
(Prior Code, § 5-203)
   (D)   A person violating §
70.04 may, upon conviction, be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $750.
(Prior Code, § 5-204)
   (E)   Violation of §
70.07 is punishable by a fine not to exceed $750.
(Prior Code, § 5-208)
(Ord. 1982, passed - -; Ord. 83-30, passed 12-20-1983; Ord. 85-6, passed 6- -
1985; Ord. 87-27, passed 11-17-1987; Ord. 00-22, passed 11-7-2000; Ord. 09-11,
passed 5-19-2009; Ord. 2021-12, passed 10-5-2021)
CHAPTER 71: PARKING REGULATIONS
Section
   
71.01   Regulation of parking zones
   
71.02   Handicapped parking
   
71.03   Owner of vehicle responsible for parking violations
   
71.04   Parking of specified mobile homes, motor coaches, trailers, semi-
tractors, semi-trailers or recreational vehicles in residential zones
prohibited
   
71.05   Parking in certain locations prohibited
§ 71.01 REGULATION OF PARKING ZONES.
   (A)   The governing body shall have the authority upon the vote of a
majority of its members to regulate, restrict, prohibit or otherwise control in
any appropriate manner all parking on any street, alley, public parking lot,
public right-of-way, public property or any portion thereof within the
corporate limits of the city.
   (B)   Whenever the governing body exercises the authority granted in
division (A) above, the Public Works Director or Chief of Police shall cause to
be erected in the locations affected appropriate signs advising the public of
the parking regulations and restrictions so imposed.
   (C)   With the approval of the governing body of the city, any owner of real
property within the city may reserve parking spaces for the handicapped and
erect signs in accordance with Wyo. Stat. § 31-5-501(b) and §
71.02. The signs and parking restrictions and regulations reserving parking
spaces for the handicapped under this section shall be enforceable under §
71.02.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in violation
of any rules, regulations, restrictions or other conditions imposed by the
governing body of the city.
(Prior Code, § 5-301) (Ord. 92-27, passed 9-15-1992) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.02 HANDICAPPED PARKING.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in a parking
space designated for the use of the handicapped unless the vehicle is in fact
being used by a handicapped person and there is visibly displayed on the
vehicle or inside the vehicle and issued pursuant to these provisions:
      (1)   A valid disabled veteran license plate;
      (2)   A valid handicapped parking permit identification card; and
      (3)   A valid city temporary handicapped parking permit identification
card.
   (B)   The Director of Engineering and Operations, upon authority of the
governing body as exercised pursuant to the provisions of §
71.01(A), shall designate the location and spaces for handicapped parking of
vehicles displaying a valid disabled veteran license plate or valid handicapped
parking permit identification cards issued pursuant to these provisions. Such
designation shall include marking of public parking spaces with a sign which is
erected in accordance with Wyo. Stat. § 31-5-501(b), in addition to any other
appropriate markings placed upon the pavement or curb. The sign shall be
painted blue in color, with a symbol of an individual in a wheelchair, painted
white in the middle of the blue area and which states thereon “Handicapped
Parking Only.”
   (C)   For the purpose of this section, a vehicle using designated
“Handicapped Parking Only” spaces shall display one of the following:
      (1)   A valid disabled veteran license plate issued by the County
Treasurer pursuant to the provisions of Wyo. Stat. § 31-2-215, as amended;
      (2)   A handicapped parking permit identification card issued pursuant to
the provisions of Wyo. Stat. § 31-2-213, as amended; and
      (3)   (a)   A city temporary handicapped parking permit identification
card which may be issued by the City Clerk to any person who has a temporary
mobility handicap.
         (b)   For the purpose of this section, TEMPORARY MOBILITY HANDICAP
means any physical condition which is certified by a licensed physician to
prohibit a person from normal ambulatory movement for a period expected to last
less than 12 consecutive months.
(Prior Code, § 5-302) (Ord. 89-36, passed 1-16-1990; Ord. 92-27, passed 9-15-
1992) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.03 OWNER OF VEHICLE RESPONSIBLE FOR PARKING VIOLATIONS.
   The registered owner of any vehicle found parked and unattended in violation
of any ordinance, or valid regulation or restriction enacted pursuant to any
ordinance, shall bear the responsibility for such parking violation and the
payment of any fine imposed whether or not said owner did in fact park the
vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 5-303) (Ord. 84-13, passed 7- -1984) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.04 PARKING OF SPECIFIED MOBILE HOMES, MOTOR COACHES, TRAILERS, SEMI-
TRACTORS, SEMI-TRAILERS OR RECREATIONAL VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL ZONES
PROHIBITED.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      MOBILE HOME. Any movable, single-family dwelling unit, designed for long-
term occupancy, built on a chassis at a factory, not less than eight feet wide
and 32 feet long, with or without a permanent foundation, and consisting of a
complete package with major appliances, plumbing and electrical facilities
prepared for appropriate connections.
      MOTOR COACH. Any wheeled motor vehicle which is a single self-contained
unit with motive powers which is designated and generally used for short-term
occupancy by persons for residential purposes.
      PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY. Any street, thoroughfare, highway, alley, sidewalk,
utility easement or other such right-of-way dedicated to the use of the public.
      RECREATIONAL VEHICLE. Any vehicle designed primarily for use as a
portable temporary dwelling unit for travel, recreational or camping purposes,
either self-propelled or mounted on or towed by another powered vehicle.
      RESIDENTIAL ZONE. The zones as identified in
Chapter 157 and the city’s master plan as R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5 or R-
6 residential zones.
      SEMI-TRACTOR. Any motor vehicle designed, exclusively or primarily, to
haul or pull trailers (specifically semi-trailers) and/or other road vehicles
which are not power-driven.
      SEMI-TRAILER. Any trailer-type vehicle, designed and used in such a way
that some part of its own weight and its own load rests on or is carried by the
motor vehicle that tows it.
      TRAILER. Any type of wheeled vehicle, regardless of the use for which it
is designed, which is to be pulled by any motor vehicle.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle exceeding 20 feet in
length, or any mobile home, motor coach, trailer or recreational vehicle, or
part of such vehicle, to be parked or stored upon any public right-of-way in
any area zoned a residential district in the city except:
      (1)   Commercial vehicles, when such vehicles are being expeditiously
loaded or unloaded, or equipment on such vehicles is being used to perform the
special operation for which it was designed; and
      (2)   Mobile homes, motor coaches, trailers or recreational vehicles,
when parked for a time period not exceeding 100 hours.
         (a)   Moving such mobile home, motor coach, trailer or recreational
vehicle from one location to another on any public right-of-way or from one
such right-of-way to another shall not excuse the violation nor toll the 100-
hour time limit.
         (b)   This division (B) shall be liberally construed to effect the
purpose of getting and keeping such mobile homes, motor coaches, trailers,
semi-trailers or recreational vehicles off of public rights-of-way in
residential neighborhoods.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful to park or store any semi-tractor, semi-trailer
or any combination thereof upon any public right-of-way in any area of the city
that is zoned as a residential district. This provision shall not prohibit
commercial vehicles from temporarily stopping in residential areas to make
deliveries or pick-ups; nor shall it preclude utility or government vehicles
from temporarily stopping in residential areas on service calls or other
official business.
(Prior Code, § 5-304) (Ord. 85-20, passed 12-3-1985; Ord. 85-26, passed 1-21-
1986; Ord. 2008-22, passed 10-21-2008) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.05 PARKING IN CERTAIN LOCATIONS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle within an alley
excepting only for the purpose of the expeditious loading or unloading of said
vehicle and then only if the vehicle is not left unattended and can be quickly
moved out of the right-of-way to allow the immediate passage of other vehicles.
   (B)   No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle for any length of time
for any reason with any portion of the vehicle adjacent to any curb or paving
that has been painted yellow by the city. Such yellow areas shall constitute a
no parking zone at all times.
(Prior Code, § 5-305) (Ord. 1938, passed - -; Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 149,
passed 11-4-1917; Ord. 2184, passed 4-1-1974; Ord. 82-47, passed 9-7-1982; Ord.
83-22, passed 9-6-1983; Ord. 83-25, passed 10-4-1983; Ord. 83-26, passed 10-4-
1983; Ord. 83-30, passed 12-20-1983; Ord. 86-14, passed 10-7-1986) Penalty, see
§
70.99
CHAPTER 72: RECREATIONAL VEHICLES
Section
Motorized Skateboards
   
72.01   Regulation of motorized skateboards on streets and bike paths
Shared Electric Scooter Program
   
72.15   Definitions
   
72.16   Shared electric scooter program permit
   
72.17   Denial, suspension or revocation of a permit
   
72.18   Operating regulations
   
72.19   Parking regulations
   
72.20   Data sharing
   
72.21   Insurance requirements
   
72.22   Indemnification
 
   
72.99   Penalty
MOTORIZED SKATEBOARDS
§ 72.01 REGULATION OF MOTORIZED SKATEBOARDS ON STREETS AND BIKE PATHS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      DAYLIGHT HOURS. One-half hour before sunrise and one-half hour after
sunset.
      MOTORIZED SKATEBOARD. A self-propelled device which has a motor or
engine, a deck on which a person may ride and at least two wheels in contact
with the ground and which is not otherwise defined under state law as a MOTOR
VEHICLE, MOTOR CYCLE, MOTOR-DRIVEN CYCLE or PEDESTRIAN VEHICLE.
   (B)   No person shall operate a motorized skateboard in violation of this
section. A violation of this section is a misdemeanor.
   (C)   All persons riding a motorized skateboard must be age ten or older,
and a helmet must be worn at all times.
   (D)   Motorized skateboards, which include electric scooters as described in
§§
72.15 through
72.22, shall be operated exclusively in locations designated by the governing
body as being appropriate for motorized skateboards.
   (E)   Unless they are equipped with appropriate front and rear lights
visible from a distance of at least 500 feet, motorized skateboards may be
operated during daylight hours only.
   (F)   Motorized skateboards must be operated in accordance with all traffic
signs. Every person operating a motorized skateboard has all of the rights and
all of the duties applicable to the operator of any vehicle under state
statutes and this traffic code, except as to any special regulations contained
in §§
72.15 through
72.22, and except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no
application.
   (G)   Motorized skateboards shall not be used to tow any apparatus; and only
one rider shall ride a motorized skateboard.
(Prior Code, § 5-207) Penalty, see §
72.99
SHARED ELECTRIC SCOOTER PROGRAM
§ 72.15 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY. The City of Rock Springs, Wyoming.
   CONTRACT. A memorandum of understanding issued between the city and the
operator that outlines the requirements and responsibilities of the operator in
the operation of the shared electric scooter program.
   FARE. The portion of the charge for rental of a shared electric scooter that
is automatically calculated by an app or comparable technology through the
operation of the mileage and/or time mechanism.
   OPERATOR. A person or entity with whom the city has contracted to provide
shared electric scooters within the city through issuance of a shared electric
scooter program permit.
   REBALANCE. Moving dockless vehicles from an area of low demand to an area of
high demand.
   SHARED ELECTRIC SCOOTER. A device weighing less than 150 pounds that:
      (1)   Has handlebars and an electric motor;
      (2)   Is solely powered by the electric motor and/or human power; and
      (3)   Has maximum speed of no more than 20 mph on a paved level surface
when powered solely by the electric motor.
   SHARED ELECTRIC SCOOTER PROGRAM. The offering, through an approved contract
with the city, of shared electric scooters, for a fare, that a customer is not
required to return to a docking station at the conclusion of a ride.
(Prior Code, § 10-1001)
§ 72.16 SHARED ELECTRIC SCOOTER PROGRAM PERMIT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a person to operate, or cause to be operated,
a shared electric scooter program, hereafter referred to as “program,” in the
public right-of-way in the city, unless the operator first obtains a shared
electric scooter program permit, hereafter referred to as “permit.”
   (B)   Applications for a permit under this subchapter shall be made on forms
provided by the city and shall be signed by an officer or employee of the
operator with authority to legally bind the operator, who shall verify under
oath that the information contained in the application is true and accurate.
   (C)   Applications for a shared electric scooter program permit shall be
submitted to the city concurrently with the operator’s occupational tax
application.
   (D)   The permit fee for a shared electric scooter program permit shall be
$500.
   (E)   Shared electric scooter program permits shall expire on December 31
each year.
   (F)   Applications for renewal shall be submitted at least 30 days prior to
the expiration of such permit. The renewal for a shared electric scooter
program permit shall be issued in the same manner and on payment of the same
fees as for an original application for said shared electric scooter program
permit.
   (G)   The operator shall provide a draft contract that includes the
following information with his or her application for a permit:
      (1)   The maximum number of shared electric scooters proposed to be used
in the program;
      (2)   A description of all shared electric scooters that will be used in
the program, including the model, manufacturer and color of each shared
electric scooter;
      (3)   Color photographs depicting the shared electric scooters to be used
in the program;
      (4)   A GPS or GIS based map, depicting the proposed service area of the
program;
      (5)   A 24-hour customer service telephone number (for voice and text)
and email address (both of which must be displayed on each shared electric
scooter to be used in the program);
      (6)   The address or addresses of any fixed facilities or locations to be
used in the operation, including proposed set daily drop off locations, if any;
      (7)   The name of the person designated by the operator as the Fleet
Manager, to receive on behalf of the operator any future notices sent by the
city to the operator, and that person’s contact information, including a
mailing address, telephone number and email or other electronic address;
      (8)   The rules and regulations for the users of the shared electric
scooters;
      (9)   Proof of public liability coverage;
      (10)   A maintenance plan;
      (11)   A staffing plan;
      (12)   Detailed plan for reporting issues with the system; and
      (13)   Any other information deemed necessary by the city.
   (H)   The contract shall be approved by the City Council prior to operation
of the shared electric scooter program.
   (I)   If, in the operation of the program, the operator modifies any of the
information required under division (G) above, the operator shall inform the
city of each modification within five business days of such modification. If
the information reported to the city under this section includes an increase in
the number of shared electric scooters, any additional fees due under this
section must be submitted simultaneously with the change in information.
(Prior Code, § 10-1002) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.17 DENIAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF A PERMIT.
   (A)   Denial of a shared electric scooter program permit. The city shall
refuse to issue or renew a permit if the applicant does or has done any of the
following at any time:
      (1)   Intentionally or knowingly makes a false statement in an
application for a permit or permit renewal;
      (2)   Violates any provision of this subchapter twice within a 12-month
period;
      (3)   Fails to remove illegally parked shared electric scooters in a
timely manner, as determined by the city;
      (4)   Fails to regulate users of its shared electric scooters to ensure
the users comply with this subchapter;
      (5)   Displays the inability to follow any operating regulations outlined
in §
72.18 or within the contract; or
      (6)   Violates any other laws or ordinances of the city related to the
subject of this subchapter.
   (B)   Suspension or revocation of permit.
      (1)   The city shall suspend or revoke a permit if the city determines
that the operator has:
         (a)   Made false statements as to a material matter in the application
concerning the permit;
         (b)   Failed to maintain the insurance required under this subchapter;
         (c)   Operated shared electric scooters in excess of the number
authorized in the permit;
         (d)   Failed to pay any fees required by this subchapter;
         (e)   Failed to remove illegally parked shared electric scooters in a
timely manner, as determined by the city;
         (f)   Failed to regulate users who have failed to follow regulations;
or
         (g)   Failed to follow any operating regulations outlined in §
72.18 or within the contract.
      (2)   After revocation of a permit, an operator is not eligible to apply
for another permit for a period of 12 months.
   (C)   Appeals.
      (1)   If the city determines that a permit should be denied, suspended or
revoked, the city shall notify the operator in writing and include in the
notice the specific reason or reasons for the denial, suspension or revocation
of the permit.
      (2)   Any operator whose application for a permit is denied, suspended or
revoked by the city may file an appeal with the governing body. Any appeal
shall be filed no more than 30 days from the written notice of the denial,
suspension or revocation.
(Prior Code, § 10-1003)
§ 72.18 OPERATING REGULATIONS.
   (A)    The city may impose appropriate conditions on the operation of
program in order to further the purposes of this subchapter, including, but not
limited to, the following:
      (1)   Limits on the locations in which the program users may operate;
      (2)   Limits on the locations where shared electric scooters may be
stored or parked when not in use;
      (3)   Limits on the hours that a shared electric scooter in a program may
operate;
      (4)   Limits on the number of shared electric scooters permitted in the
program;
      (5)   Standards for the use and maintenance of shared electric scooters;
and
      (6)   Any other regulations necessary to further the purposes of this
subchapter.
   (B)   The operator shall employ a Fleet Manager, who shall maintain a
consistent and regular physical presence in the city.
   (C)   Notwithstanding any other section of the city code, a person using a
shared electric scooter shall operate it in the same manner as directed by
state law and local ordinance for bicycles, unless otherwise posted, subject to
regulation by the city. Shared electric scooters cannot be operated on shared-
use paths where marked as prohibited. This section shall not be read to modify
the use of bicycles currently in effect nor change the rules of the road
applicable to bicycles.
   (D)   Shared electric scooters in a program shall be maintained continuously
in a reasonably clean and working condition.
   (E)   Each shared electric scooter used in a program shall have a unique
identification number that is visible to the user and nearby pedestrians that
identifies both the operator and the shared electric scooter.
   (F)   The operator shall maintain a website and a telephone service with a
live person or persons who are available 24 hours a day. Each shared electric
scooter used in a program shall have a posted notice, which shall be in
compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq.
requirements, advising users of the operator’s 24-hour telephone number,
website, email address and any mobile application information.
   (G)   The speed of shared electric scooters shall not exceed a maximum speed
of 15 mph.
   (H)   Each shared electric scooter shall be equipped with the following, if
operated after sunset or before sunrise:
      (1)   A lamp on the front, exhibiting a white light visible from a
distance of at least 500 feet to the front; and
      (2)   A lamp on the rear, exhibiting a red light visible from a distance
of at least 500 feet to the rear.
   (I)   There shall be only one person on a shared electric scooter at any
time.
   (J)   A user may not ride a shared electric scooter while controlling an
animal, either by hand or on a leash.
   (K)   A user may not push, pull, tow or haul any other items while riding a
shared electric scooter. Items worn by a user are allowable.
   (L)   An operator may not permit any person under the age of 16 years to use
a shared electric scooter in a program.
   (M)   The operator shall require a user to individually agree to each of the
following conditions before the operator may allow the user to access the
program, and annually thereafter:
      (1)   The user shall follow all traffic laws, such as not operating on
sidewalks;
      (2)   The user shall yield to pedestrians;
      (3)   The user shall follow proper parking procedures; and
      (4)   The user is encouraged to wear a helmet.
   (N)   Each shared electric scooter used in a program shall have clearly
visible advisements in substantially the following form:
      (1)   Sidewalk riding is prohibited;
      (2)   The user shall yield to pedestrians;
      (3)   The user may not operate the shared electric scooter while
intoxicated; and
      (4)   The user shall park in designated areas.
   (O)   The operator shall provide users with a mechanism to report a crash
through the operator’s mobile application or posted phone number.
(Prior Code, § 10-1004)
§ 72.19 PARKING REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The operator shall ensure that shared electric scooters are parked in
accordance with the terms and performance measures outlined in the contract,
permit requirements and in compliance with all state and local laws.
   (B)   The operator shall work to ensure that shared electric scooters are
parked in a manner that: does not impede pedestrian access; does not obstruct
access to fire hydrants and valves, street furniture, crosswalks, driveways or
private property; does not damage landscaping, street trees or other aesthetic
features; and does not interfere with traffic operations.
   (C)   Shared electric scooters shall be upright when parked.
   (D)   The operator shall conduct outreach and education to its users on
proper parking practices and shall continue developing and implementing
technical solutions to ensure good parking behavior.
   (E)   All staging areas shall be approved by the City Engineer and outlined
in the contract.
   (F)   Any shared electric scooter parked on private property is subject to
the requirements of that property owner and may be towed at any time at the
operator’s expense.
   (G)   After receiving a report from the city or others, the operator shall
remove shared electric scooters parked in violation of the parking requirements
outlined above, or otherwise in conflict with applicable laws and regulations.
   (H)   Shared electric scooters are not permitted to park in one single
approximate location in the public right-of-way for more than seven consecutive
days without rental.
   (I)   Failure to adhere to these parking requirements may result in the city
removing the shared electric scooter and storing it in a city facility. The
operator shall be required to pick up shared electric scooters from such a
facility and shall be liable for all costs associated with removal and storage
of the shared electric scooter, in addition to any applicable fines or fees, or
other penalties as appropriate under the law. Subject to applicable laws and
regulations, the city shall consider the shared electric scooter abandoned and
dispose of it as the city determines fit in the event that the operator fails
to retrieve the device within five business days upon being notified of the
removal and storage.
(Prior Code, § 10-1005)
§ 72.20 DATA SHARING.
   (A)   An operator shall cooperate with the city in the collection and
analysis of aggregated data concerning its operations.
   (B)   An operator shall provide a monthly report to the city that includes:
      (1)   Total number of rides for the previous month;
      (2)   Total number of vehicles in service for the previous month;
      (3)   Number of rides per vehicle per day;
      (4)   Anonymized aggregated data taken by the operator’s dockless
vehicles in the form of heat maps showing routes, trends, origins and
destinations; and
      (5)   Anonymized trip data taken by the operator’s dockless vehicles that
includes the origin and destination, trip duration and date and time of trip.
   (C)   An operator shall provide other reports at the city’s request.
(Prior Code, § 10-1006)
§ 72.21 INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   The operator shall provide city with proof of insurance coverage
exclusively for the operation of shared electric scooters including:
      (1)   Commercial general liability insurance coverage with a limit of no
less than $1,000,000 each occurrence and $2,000,000 aggregate;
      (2)   Automobile insurance coverage with a limit of no less than
$1,000,000 each occurrence and $1,000,000 aggregate; and
      (3)   Where operator employs persons within the city, workers’
compensation coverage of no less than the statutory requirement.
   (B)   Certificates of insurance naming the city as an additional insured
showing such coverage then in force, but not less than the above amounts, shall
be submitted by the operator with its application for a permit under this
subchapter. Such certificates shall contain a provision that the policies and
coverage afforded thereunder will not be canceled or reduced until at least 30
days after written notice to the city.
(Prior Code, § 10-1007)
§ 72.22 INDEMNIFICATION.
   (A)   The operator agrees to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city
(and its officials, employees and agents) from and against all actions, damages
or claims, including reasonable attorneys’ fees (collectively “claims”),
brought against the city for personal or bodily injury or death to any person,
or damage or destruction of any property, arising out of or resulting from
performance or breach of the permit, provided that such claim, damage, loss or
expense is:
      (1)   Attributable to personal injury, bodily injury, sickness, death or
destruction of property, including the loss of use resulting therefrom, or
breach of contract; and
      (2)   Not caused by the negligent act or omission or willful misconduct
of the city or its elected and appointed officials and employees acting within
the scope of their employment.
   (B)   The city expressly acknowledges that in no event shall the operator be
liable for any special, indirect, consequential or punitive damages.
   (C)   The city’s right to indemnification shall be contingent on the city
notifying the operator promptly following receipt or notice of any claims.
   (D)   The operator shall have sole control of any defense, including the
ability to choose counsel.
   (E)   The city shall not consent to the entry of a judgment or enter into
any settlement without the prior written consent of the operator.
(Prior Code, § 10-1008)
§ 72.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99.
   (B)   Whoever violates any provision of §§
72.15 through
72.22 for which no penalty is provided shall be punishable by a fine of not
more than $750, a jail sentence of not more than six months, or both, to which
restitution may be added by the trial court. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.
(Prior Code, § 10-1009)
CHAPTER 73: TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
Schedule
      
I.   Streets maintained as public highways
SCHEDULE I. STREETS MAINTAINED AS PUBLIC HIGHWAYS.
   (A)   M Street. The portion of M Street between North Front Street and Pilot
Butte Avenue shall be maintained as a public highway with a pavement width of
43 feet.
(Prior Code, § 6-501)
   (B)   North Front Street. The portion of North Front Street between M Street
and Elk Street shall be maintained as a public highway with a pavement width of
69 feet.
(Prior Code, § 6-502)
   (C)   South Main Street. The portion of South Main Street between E Street
and C Street shall be maintained as a public highway with a pavement width of
70 feet.
(Prior Code, § 6-503)
   (D)   Fourth Street. The portion of Fourth Street between A Street and the
southerly entrance to the subway at M Street shall be maintained as a public
highway with a pavement width of 57 feet.
(Prior Code, § 6-504)
   (E)   Grant Street. The portion of Grant Street between Elk Street and the
railroad company’s tracks shall be maintained as a public highway with a
pavement width of 65 feet, and a pavement width of 50 feet on Grant Street and
Elk Street on the line of the viaduct.
(Prior Code, § 6-505)
   (F)   Elk Street. The portion of Elk Street between North Front Street and
Bridger Avenue shall be maintained as a public highway, and the pavement shall
have a width of at least 44 feet between Evans Street and Bridger Avenue.
(Prior Code, § 6-506)
   (G)   Certain streets to remain public highways. The streets mentioned in
divisions (A) through (F) above, which are to be maintained as public highways
according to the terms of an agreement between the Union Pacific Railroad
Company, the state and the city, dated May 28, 1940, shall not be closed as
public highways, and that this schedule shall become effective upon completion
and opening of the A Street viaduct and the M Street subway.
(Prior Code, § 6-507)
(Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 655, passed 6-3-1940)
TITLE IX: GENERAL REGULATIONS
