CHAPTER 110: BUSINESS LICENSING
Section
Contractor Licensing
   
110.01   Purpose and objective
   
110.02   Definitions
   
110.03   General requirements
   
110.04   Fees
 
   
110.99   Penalty
CONTRACTOR LICENSING
§ 110.01 PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVE.
   It is hereby determined to be necessary for the purposes of public health
and safety and welfare, building safety and minimal consumer protection, that
contractors doing business within the city be registered and/or licensed.
(Prior Code, § 7-601)
§ 110.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY. The City of Rock Springs.
   CONTRACTOR, SUBCONTRACTOR or BUILDER. Any person, firm, corporation or other
organization who or which is in the pursuit of an independent business
undertaking to construct, alter, repair, add to, subtract from, improve, move,
wreck or demolish, for another, any building structure, highway, road, lot or
area within the city.
   MAY. The act referred to is permissive.
   SHALL. The act referred to is mandatory.
(Prior Code, § 7-601)
§ 110.03 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Registration.
      (1)   Any contractor, subcontractor or builder shall register with the
city prior to commencing any work activities. Registration shall be
accomplished through the filing with the Building Inspections Office
appropriate forms indicating the name and business address of the contractor,
subcontractor or builder.
      (2)   The term of registration shall be one year from the date of
original application for registration and shall be renewed yearly. Properly
registered contractors, subcontractors or builders shall be considered to be in
compliance with the city occupational licensing requirements. The fee for
initial registrants shall be $125. The fee for renewal of registration shall be
$100. Renewal of registration shall be made within 15 days of expiration.
Application for renewal received more than 15 days after the expiration of
registration shall be treated as applications for original registration.
   (B)   Liability insurance.
      (1)   At the time of registration, the contractor, subcontractor or
builder shall file with the city a current certificate of insurance. The
minimum insurance coverage shall be as follows.
 
Injury or damage that includes death to any one person       $100,000
Injury or damage that includes death to more than one person $250,000
Injury or damage to property                                 $100,000
 
      (2)   Said insurance certificate shall be provided by the insurance
company of the contractor, subcontractor or builder in a form which is
satisfactory and acceptable to the city and which shows the city as a
certificate holder.
   (C)   The name and phone number of contractor must be visibly displayed with
two-inch minimum letter size on all large equipment and vehicles used or parked
at construction sites. Signage must be permanently affixed or magnetically
adhered. Failure to do so will result in work stoppage for contractor out of
compliance.
(Prior Code, § 7-601) (Ord. 94-20, passed 7-5-1994; Ord. 2006-12, passed 5-16-
2006; Ord. 2012-10, passed 12-18-2012)
§ 110.04 FEES.
   (A)   Initial registration. All contractors, subcontractors or builders
shall pay an initial registration fee of $125. This will include those
contractors, subcontractors or builders that allow the original registration to
expire.
   (B)   Renewal fee. All contractors, subcontractors and builders must renew
their registration if they are continuously to work within the city. Renewal
fees paid within 15 days of the expiration of the original registration shall
be $100. Renewals received 15 days after expiration shall be the same as
defined in division (A) above.
(Prior Code, § 7-601) (Ord. 2006-12, passed 5-16-2006; Ord. 2013-01, passed 3-
5-2013)
§ 110.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99.
   (B)   (1)   Any contractor, subcontractor or builder commencing work prior
to paying the registration fee and providing a proper certificate of insurance
as described in §
110.03(B) shall be subject to a $250 penalty in addition to the fees required
for contractors registration in §
110.04(A).
      (2)   Any contractor, subcontractor or builder who fails to call for a
required inspection, or who does not call for re-inspection after deficiencies
have been noted on a correction notice, may be denied inspections on any
project, and no new permits shall be issued until the required inspections have
been completed and approved by the Building Official.
(Prior Code, § 7-601) (Ord. 91-21, passed 2-4-1992; Ord. 2006-12, passed 5-16-
2006; Ord. 2013-01, passed 3-5-2013; Ord. 2022-02, passed 2-15-2022)
CHAPTER 111: OCCUPATIONAL TAX
Section
   
111.01   Purpose and authorization
   
111.02   Definitions
   
111.03   Evidence of conducting business
   
111.04   Exemptions of charitable and nonprofit organizations
   
111.05   License required
   
111.06   Separate licenses
   
111.07   Application procedure
   
111.08   Termination of licenses
   
111.09   Transfer of licenses
   
111.10   Posting license
   
111.11   Revocation of license
   
111.12   Fees
   
111.13   Expositions
§ 111.01 PURPOSE AND AUTHORIZATION.
   (A)   The city has received express authorization to tax any business which
is conducted within the city pursuant to Wyo. Stat. § 15-1-103(a)(xiii). The
purpose of this business tax is to raise revenue to provide services to the
public.
   (B)   For the purpose of establishing the amounts to be levied and collected
under this chapter, businesses and callings are classified for said tax as set
forth in division (C) below.
   (C)   (1)   Class A.
         (a)   Embraces all railroad companies and agencies each for business
done exclusively within the city, and not including any business done to or
from points without the state, and not including any business done for the
government of the United States, its officers or agents.
         (b)   A tax of $800 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
such railroad company or agency, as to its urban business, as aforesaid.
      (2)   Class B.
         (a)   All express companies and agencies, each for business done
exclusively within the city, and not including any business done to and from
points without the state, and not including any business done for the
government of the United States, its officers or agents, and this shall include
auto vehicle express companies as well as rail express companies and agencies.
         (b)   A tax of $100 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
express company or agency, as to its urban business, as aforesaid.
      (3)   Class C.
         (a)   All telegraph companies and agencies, each for business done
exclusively within the city, and not including any business done to and from
points without the state, and not including any business done for the
government of the United States, its officers or agents.
         (b)   A tax of $40 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
such telegraph company or agency, as to its urban business, as aforesaid.
      (4)   Class D-1.
         (a)   All telephone and other telecommunications companies and
agencies, each for business done exclusively within the city, and not including
any business done for the government of the United States, its officers and
agents.
         (b)   A tax equivalent to 2% of the gross revenue received for
telephone and other telecommunication services rendered to persons within the
corporate limits of the city. Said tax shall be due at the end of each calendar
quarter and shall be paid within 45 days from the end of said quarter. Any
amount paid to the city as a franchise tax by reason of a franchise or separate
agreement shall be credited as a part payment upon the tax herein provided for.
      (5)   Class D-2.
         (a)   All community television systems, each for business done
exclusively within the city, and not including any business done to or from
points without the state.
         (b)   A tax equivalent to 2% of the gross amount received as monthly
service charge from users within the corporate limits of the city. Said tax
shall be due at the end of each calendar quarter and shall be paid within 45
days from the end of said quarter. Any amount paid to the city as a franchise
tax by reason of a franchise or separate agreement shall be credited as a part
payment upon the tax herein provided for.
      (6)   Class E.
         (a)   All electric power and lighting companies and agencies, each for
business done exclusively within the city, and not including any business done
to or from points without the state.
         (b)   A tax equivalent to 2% of the gross amount received for power
and light sold or furnished to persons within the corporate limits of the city.
Said taxes shall be due at the end of each calendar quarter and shall be paid
within 45 days from the end of the said quarter. Any amount paid to the city as
a franchise tax by reason of a franchise or separate agreement shall be
credited as a part payment upon the tax herein provided for.
      (7)   Class F.
         (a)   All public utility gas companies and agencies, each for business
done exclusively within the city, and not including any business done to or
from points without the state.
         (b)   A tax equivalent to 2% of the gross amount received for gas sold
or furnished to persons within the corporate limits of the city. Said tax shall
be due at the end of each calendar quarter, and shall be paid within 45 days
from the end of said quarter. Any amount paid to the city as a franchise tax by
reason of a franchise or separate agreement shall be credited as a part payment
upon the tax herein provided for.
         (c)   Where any of the companies referred to in Class D, E and F shall
be engaged in any non-utility business, they shall pay the tax provided for
said non-utility business, in addition to the amount herein provided for said
utility business.
      (8)   Class G.
         (a)   All public utility stage, bus, truck and taxicab transportation
companies and agencies, when licensed by the State Public Service Commission.
         (b)   A tax of $100 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
individual or company operating three or more stages; a tax of $75 shall be
assessed, levied and collected from each individual or company operating two
stages; a tax of $50 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
individual or company operating one stage.
         (c)   A tax of $130 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
individual or company operating three or more buses; a tax of $90 shall be
assessed, levied and collected from each individual or company operating two
buses; a tax of $50 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each company
operating one bus.
         (d)   A tax of $130 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
individual or company operating three or more trucks; a tax of $90 shall be
assessed, levied and collected from each individual or company operating two
trucks; a tax of $50 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
individual or company operating one truck.
         (e)   A tax of $60 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
individual or company operating three or more taxicabs; a tax of $35 shall be
assessed, levied and collected from each individual or company operating two
taxicabs; a tax of $20 shall be assessed, levied and collected from each
individual or company operating one taxicab. In addition to the foregoing, each
individual or company using street parking area within an area where parking
meters are installed shall pay an additional tax of $36 per year for each car
space set aside for their use.
(Prior Code, § 9-201) (Ord. 2017-09, passed 7-18-2017)
§ 111.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BUSINESS. Any employment, occupation, profession or commercial activity
engaged in for gain or livelihood; this definition includes contractors and
subcontractors.
   EMPLOYEE. A person in the service of another, in which the employer or
supervisor has the authority to control and direct the employee in the details
of how the work is to be performed.
      (1)   An employee who performs work 20 hours per week or less shall be a
part-time employee. A part-time employee shall be designated one-half employee,
so two part-time employees shall be considered one employee for the purposes of
this chapter.
      (2)   An employee who performs work for more than 20 hours per week shall
be considered one employee.
      (3)   Seasonal employees shall be considered fractional employees,
depending on the number of months of the year they work, rounded to the nearest
quarter. A seasonal employee who works three months would be a one-fourth
employee.
   EXPOSITION. The collective display of goods or services offered by merchants
at a single location. Examples of an EXPOSITION would be gun shows or garden
shows.
   GROSS REVENUE. All revenue derived directly or indirectly by the company in
connection with the operation of its facilities for the provision of local
services supplied to customers or patrons within the city pursuant to this
chapter; provided, however, that this shall not include revenues derived from
intrastate or interstate toll services and any taxes upon the sale or
distribution of telephone and other telecommunication services furnished by the
company imposed directly upon any customer or user by the state, the city or
other governmental entity, and collected by the company on behalf of said
state, city or governmental entity.
   TELECOMMUNICATIONS. The exchange of information by electronic means and
refers to all types of voice, data and video transmission. This term includes a
wide range of information transmitting technologies. Telecommunications systems
are, for the purpose of this chapter, run by telecommunications service
providers who offer telephone and related services, such as internet.
   TEMPORARY BUSINESS. A business which operates two or fewer times during the
calendar year.
(Prior Code, § 9-202) (Ord. 2017-09, passed 7-18-2017)
§ 111.03 EVIDENCE OF CONDUCTING BUSINESS.
   Whenever any person by the use of signs, circulars, cards, telephone books
or newspapers, advertises or represents that he or she is conducting business;
or when any person holds an active license or permit issued by a government
agency indicating that he or she is in business in the city, and such person
has not executed a denial in a sworn statement given to the City Treasurer that
he or she is not conducting business in the city, after having been provided
the opportunity to do so by the City Treasurer, then the above facts shall be
sufficient evidence for the City Treasurer to conclude that the person is
conducting business. The City Treasurer may rely on other evidence that tends
to show the existence of a business.
(Prior Code, § 9-203)
§ 111.04 EXEMPTIONS OF CHARITABLE AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS.
   (A)   The provisions of this chapter do not apply to institutions or
organizations which are managed or conducted for religious, charitable,
philanthropic or educational purposes.
   (B)   To establish an exemption, evidence should be given to the City
Treasurer that not less than 75% of the gross receipts derived from the
business, occupation, event or activity will be provided to a religious,
charitable, philanthropic or education purpose.
(Prior Code, § 9-204)
§ 111.05 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful and declared to be a misdemeanor, punishable under §
10.99, for any person to carry on or conduct a business without having complied
with the provisions of this chapter by paying an occupation or exhibitors fee.
(Prior Code, § 9-205) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 111.06 SEPARATE LICENSES.
   A separate license must be obtained for each branch, establishment or
separate place of business in which the business is conducted.
(Prior Code, § 9-206)
§ 111.07 APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   An application for an annual business license must be submitted and approved
prior to beginning operations. Applications for all business licenses shall be
in writing, on a form approved by the City Treasurer. Each applicant must state
his or her name, the name of the business and the location in which the
business is conducted. The applicant must also provide the number of employees,
whether part-time, full-time or seasonal, that perform work for the business.
(Prior Code, § 9-207)
§ 111.08 TERMINATION OF LICENSES.
   All licenses shall terminate on February 14 each year if there has been no
accepted reapplication.
(Prior Code, § 9-208)
§ 111.09 TRANSFER OF LICENSES.
   (A)   Any applicant may apply to the City Treasurer to transfer a license to
another location. There shall be no additional fee unless the business
increases its employees by the transfer.
   (B)   It is unlawful and a misdemeanor to transfer a business license to any
other person or entity.
(Prior Code, § 9-209) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 111.10 POSTING LICENSE.
   All successful applicants for a business license shall post at all times, in
a prominent place, a current copy of the business license.
(Prior Code, § 9-210)
§ 111.11 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The City Treasurer, after consulting the Mayor, may revoke a business
license for violating the provisions of this chapter by misrepresenting the
number of employees or the nature of the business to achieve a material gain.
(Prior Code, § 9-211)
§ 111.12 FEES.
   (A)   Payment. Fees are nonrefundable unless an application is denied.
(Prior Code, § 9-212)
   (B)   Amount.
      (1)   (a)   Businesses who employ 15 or more employees shall pay an
annual occupation fee of $100.
         (b)   Businesses who employ 14 or fewer employees shall pay an annual
occupation fee of $50.
         (c)   Temporary businesses shall pay an occupation fee of $10 per
month and a one-time filing fee of $10. The fee for each additional month in
the calendar year shall be $25.
         (d)   For railroads, express companies, telephone companies,
television systems, electric power and lighting companies, gas companies and
public utility, stage, bus, truck and taxi cab companies, the fee schedule
shall be as listed in §
111.01.
      (2)   The city shall add a penalty of 10% per month of the license tax
plus the cost of collection for failure to pay the license tax when due
starting 60 days after the due date as shown on the statement.
(Prior Code, § 9-213)
(Ord. 2017-09, passed 7-18-2017)
§ 111.13 EXPOSITIONS.
   (A)   The organizer or promoter shall be obligated to pay an exhibitor’s fee
as follows.
      (1)   For ten or fewer booths, the promoter shall pay an exhibitor’s fee
in the amount of $50.
      (2)   For 11 or more booths, the promoter shall pay an exhibitor’s fee in
the amount of $100.
      (3)   All exhibitor’s fees shall be paid prior to the exposition.
      (4)   The number of booths shall consist of those booths which will be
occupied by a vendor.
   (B)   The promoter must pay either an occupation fee or a temporary business
fee, if the promoter qualifies as a temporary business.
(Prior Code, § 9-214) (Ord. 2005-13, passed 9-20-2005)
CHAPTER 112: AMUSEMENTS
Section
Bingo and Pull Tab Regulations
   
112.01   General regulations
   
112.02   Definitions
   
112.03   Requirement of license
   
112.04   Financial responsibility
   
112.05   Conduct of games
   
112.06   Restriction on players
   
112.07   Posting of odds
   
112.08   Pull tabs, use of
   
112.09   Examination of books, records and personnel
   
112.10   Gratuities prohibited
   
112.11   Severability; general repealer; effective date
 
   
112.99   Penalty
BINGO AND PULL TAB REGULATIONS
§ 112.01 GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (A)   It is hereby declared that the unregulated conduct of games of chance
sponsored by nonprofit organizations is a threat to the health, safety and
welfare of the citizens of the city.
   (B)   It is further declared that the purpose of this subchapter is to:
      (1)   Protect the health, safety and welfare of the public;
      (2)   Protect the economic welfare and interest in fair play of
participants in games of chance;
      (3)   Ensure that the fund-raising potential of games of chance are
fairly and fully available to nonprofit organizations within the county;
      (4)   Prevent purposes for which games of chance are sponsored by
nonprofit organizations from being subverted by improper elements; and
      (5)   Monitor and control the organization, sponsorship, conduct and
accounting of games of chance in order for the city to promote the public
welfare.
(Prior Code, § 3-701) (Ord. 90-04, passed 5-15-1990)
§ 112.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BINGO. A game of chance played with individual cards having randomly
numbered squares ranging from one to 75, in which prizes are awarded on the
basis of designated numbers on such cards conforming to a predetermined pattern
of numbers which are selected at random. Such cards shall have five vertical
rows headed respectively by the letters B.I.N.G.O. with each row having five
numbered or free squares. Cards may be used for multiple games (“hard cards”)
or for one game only (“specials”).
   GAMING DAY. The 24-hour period beginning at 6:00 a.m. on one calendar day
and ending at 6:00 a.m. on the succeeding calendar day.
   GROSS PROCEEDS. All money collected or received from the conduct of bingo
games, raffles, pull tabs or admissions thereto.
   MINOR. A person under the age of 18 years.
   ORGANIZATION. Any association of two or more persons, legal or natural,
associated for any legal purpose.
   PERSON. An individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public
or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private
institution, utility, cooperative, municipality or any other political
subdivision of the state, or any interstate body or any other legal entity.
   PULL TABS. Single or banded tickets or cards each with its face covered to
conceal one or more numbers or symbols, where one or more card or ticket in
each set has been designed in advance as a winner. This definition shall also
include the devices known as PICKLE CARDS, BREAK OPENS, NEVADA TICKETS, PICKLES
or similar devices.
   SET OF PULL TABS. A prepackaged group of pull tabs in which the value,
number and distribution of winning and non-winning pull tabs is known and
determined by the manufacturer. Also known as a DEAL.
(Prior Code, § 3-702)
§ 112.03 REQUIREMENT OF LICENSE.
   No person or organization shall conduct a bingo game to which the public is
invited or shall sell pull tabs to the public without a license issued by the
state under the requirements of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 3-703) (Ord. 2021-07, passed 8-3-2021) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.04 FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   The holder of any gaming license under this subchapter shall at all times
have on hand and available sufficient funds with which to pay the largest
possible daily prize or prizes, or any combination thereof, and shall make such
payment no later than the end of the next gaming day.
(Prior Code, § 3-704) (Ord. 90-04, passed 5-15-1990)
§ 112.05 CONDUCT OF GAMES.
   (A)   Any time a game is conducted for the benefit of another organization,
a bona fide volunteer member of the benefited organization shall be present at
the game.
   (B)   When the receipts from a game which was conducted for the benefit of
another organization are counted, a bona fide volunteer member of the benefited
organization shall be present and shall monitor the counting and distribution
of the proceeds.
   (C)   All games shall be organized and conducted in a fair and unbiased
manner. No activities which would reasonably be considered unfair to either the
players or the benefited organization are permitted.
   (D)   Any game conducted from 12:01 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. shall be considered to
be conducted the previous day unless no gaming session was conducted on that
day.
   (E)   All games which are advertised or otherwise published shall be played.
Games may have qualifying conditions, such as a minimum number of players, but
such conditions must be included in any advertising or other publicity.
(Prior Code, § 3-705)
§ 112.06 RESTRICTION ON PLAYERS.
   (A)   Minors may be present at a gaming session only when accompanied by a
parent or guardian. Minors may participate in the sessions only to the extent
of marking the parent’s or guardian’s bingo cards. At no other time may a minor
participate in any other gaming activity addressed in this subchapter.
   (B)   No intoxicated person or person under the influence of drugs or any
incompetent person shall be allowed to participate in any gaming activity under
this subchapter.
   (C)   No paid employee or agent of a sponsoring organization shall be
allowed to participate in any gaming activity for the benefit of that
organization.
(Prior Code, § 3-706) (Ord. 90-04, passed 5-15-1990) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.07 POSTING OF ODDS.
   (A)   There shall be posted in a conspicuous place at any location where
gaming activities are, a sign not less than 18 inches by 18 inches and lettered
no smaller than one-half inch, stating the odds of winning in each of the games
to be played at that location and at that session. The odds shall be styled:
“One chance in       chances of winning       (prize)      .”
   (B)   For bingo, the odds shall be calculated for a single bingo card played
with 99 other random bingo cards. Odds need not be posted for games with
guaranteed winners or for prizes which the odds of winning are less than 500 to
one (500:1).
   (C)   For pull tabs, the odds shall be calculated for a single pull tab from
a particular unopened set.
   (D)   Any advertising for a gaming activity must publish the odds for any
prize or combination of prizes. For the purpose of this section, ADVERTISING
includes all signs, flyers, handbills, radio, television or radio
advertisements whether published, posted or distributed in the city or not.
(Prior Code, § 3-707)
§ 112.08 PULL TABS, USE OF.
   (A)   The number and amounts of pull tabs from a set which have won or lost,
the amount of payout or any similar information which would reveal other than
the posted odds of winning or losing may be tabulated for accounting and
managerial purposes but shall not be communicated to any player or potential
player.
   (B)   No set of pull tabs may be removed from play or availability for
purchase until at least 95% of the payout for the set has been made to players.
   (C)   Any set of pull tabs must be purchased by the operator as a sealed
pre-mixed set. It is specifically forbidden for an operator to purchase or
otherwise acquire winning and non-winning pull tabs separately.
   (D)   No organization, distributor or manufacturer, or any representative
thereof, either with knowledge or in circumstances whereunder it reasonably
should have known, shall possess, display, put out for play, sell or otherwise
furnish to any person any deal of pull tabs:
      (1)   In which the winning pull tabs have not been completely and
randomly distributed and mixed among all other pull tabs in the set; or
      (2)   In which the location or approximate location of any of the winning
pull tabs can be determined in advance opening the pull tabs in any manner or
by any device, including, but not limited to, any pattern in the manufacture,
assembly or packaging of pull tabs by the manufacturer, by any markings on the
pull tabs or container, or by the use of a light or illuminating device.
(Prior Code, § 3-708) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.09 EXAMINATION OF BOOKS, RECORDS AND PERSONNEL.
   The Police Department and the governing body of the city shall have the
power to examine or cause to be examined the books and records of any
individual or organization to which a gaming license is issued so far as they
relate to any transactions connected with holding and conducting a game of
chance. Any manager, officer, director, agent, member or employee may be
questioned under oath in relation to the conduct of any game of chance, but
information shall not be disclosed except for purposes of law enforcement or
licensing or as necessary to administer this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 3-709)
§ 112.10 GRATUITIES PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person owning, operating or conducting a permitted gaming activity
shall accept any tip, gratuity or any other thing of value from any player of a
game.
   (B)   No operator, sponsoring organization, employees of an operator or
sponsoring organization shall receive either directly or indirectly any gifts,
trips, prizes, provisions or other thing of value from any manufacturer or
distributor of gaming suppliers or equipment except for nominal promotional
prizes or benefits, but in no case may the value of such prize exceed $100 per
calendar year.
(Prior Code, § 3-710) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.11 SEVERABILITY; GENERAL REPEALER; EFFECTIVE DATE.
   (A)   If any section, division, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this
subchapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and
independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the
remaining portions thereof.
   (B)   All ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.
   (C)   This subchapter shall be in full force and effect upon and after its
passage; provided, however, that any person or organization engaged in the
operation of a gaming activity at the time of the enactment of this subchapter
shall have three months, unless otherwise provided for by this subchapter, in
which to comply with the licensing provisions of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 3-712) (Ord. 89-14, passed 9-19-1989; Ord. 90-04, passed 5-15-
1990)
§ 112.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99.
   (B)   (1)   Any person or organization violating the provisions of §§
112.01 through
112.11 or causing the provisions of §§
112.01 through
112.11 to be violated shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to §
10.99. Each day of operation shall constitute a separate violation.
      (2)   Any violation of §§
112.01 through
112.11 by any manager, director, owner or supervisor of a license holding
organization shall be deemed to be a violation by the organization.
(Prior Code, § 3-711) (Ord. 90-04, passed 5-15-1990; Ord. 2021-07, passed 8-3-
2021)
CHAPTER 113: PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
Section
   
113.01   Soliciting and peddling prohibited; license required
   
113.02   Definitions
   
113.03   Permit applications
   
113.04   Fees
   
113.05   Application review and issuance of license
   
113.06   Exhibiting license
   
113.07   Transfer
   
113.08   Duty of police to enforce
   
113.09   Records and complaints
   
113.10   Prohibited practices
   
113.11   Exemptions
   
113.12   Revocation of license
   
113.13   Notice and hearing
   
113.14   Appeal
   
113.15   Severability
§ 113.01 SOLICITING AND PEDDLING PROHIBITED; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   The governing body of the city finds the practice of going in and upon
private residences and property in the city, by solicitors or peddlers, as
defined in §
113.02, to be a nuisance and a substantial safety risk to the citizens of the
city. To protect against illegal or criminal activity, minimize the unwelcome
disturbance of citizens and the disruption of privacy and to otherwise preserve
the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, it is hereby
forbidden for any solicitor or peddler, as defined in §
113.02, to enter upon private property for the purpose of soliciting orders for
the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, or for the purpose of disposing of
the same, unless the action falls under an exception included under this
chapter. Nothing in this section shall preclude lawful solicitors, peddlers
and/or mobile vendors from doing business in other areas of the city nor by
more traditional means.    
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any peddler or solicitor, as defined in §
113.02, to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a
license therefor. In the event that the peddler or solicitor is under 18 years
of age, the license shall be obtained by a sponsor, and at all times the
sponsor shall be responsible for the juvenile peddler or solicitor.
(Prior Code, § 10-301) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996; Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-
16-2021) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CLERK. City Clerk for the City of Rock Springs.
   JUVENILE. Any natural person under 18 years of age.
   PEDDLER. Any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling either
by foot, or by any other type of conveyance, from place to place, carrying,
conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables,
fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the
same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers; provided,
that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to
purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this
chapter shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this chapter.
The word PEDDLER shall include the terms HAWKER and HUCKSTER.
   PERSON. Any natural person or any firm, corporation, association, club,
society or other organization.
   SOLICITOR. Any individual, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling
either by foot, or by any type of conveyance, from place to place, for the
purpose of selling goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any
nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for offering services to be furnished
or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or
exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale, and regardless of
whether he or she is collecting advance payments on such sales and/or services;
provided, that such definition shall include any person who, for himself or
herself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any room,
building, structure, hotel room, lodging house, apartment, shop or any other
place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking
orders for future delivery. The word SOLICITOR shall include CANVASSER and
DRUMMER.
   SPONSOR. Any natural person, over the age of 18, or any company or
organization, that obtains a license required under this chapter for any
juvenile solicitor or peddler.
(Prior Code, § 10-302) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996; Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-
16-2021)
§ 113.03 PERMIT APPLICATIONS.
   Applicants for a license under this chapter shall file with the City Clerk a
written sworn application, provided by the City Clerk’s office, containing the
following information:
   (A)   The name and description of the applicant;
   (B)   The permanent home address of the applicant;
   (C)   A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be
sold;
   (D)   If operating as an employee, the name and address of the employer,
together with the credentials establishing the exact relationship;
   (E)   The length of time for which the right to do business is desired;
   (F)   The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders
taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or
products are located at the time such application is filed and the proposed
method of delivery;
   (G)   A photograph of the applicant. The photograph shall show the head and
shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner;
   (H)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant, or any of its
participating employees have been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or
violation of any municipal law, the nature of the offense or violation, the
punishment or penalty assessed therefor, the date when and place where such
offense occurred and other pertinent details thereof;
   (I)   The names, addresses and dates of birth for all employees and
associates who will be actively participating in the business within the city;
and
   (J)   A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising, if
any, to be done in order to attract customers.
(Prior Code, § 10-303) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996; Ord. 2014-06, passed 5-6-
2014)
§ 113.04 FEES.
   (A)   At the time of filing the application, a nonrefundable fee of $10
shall be paid to the City Clerk to help defray the costs of processing the
application.
   (B)   Before any license shall be issued under this chapter, the applicant
therefor shall pay a license fee based upon the length of time the applicant
intends to engage in business in the city as follows.
      (1)   The minimum license fee shall be $25 which said fee shall entitle
the licensee to conduct business in the city for a period not to exceed 30
calendar days from the date of issuance of the license.
      (2)   Licensees may obtain a permit for a period not to exceed 90 days
for a filing fee of $10 plus an additional $25 for each salesman.
      (3)   For a fee of $100, the licensee may obtain a permit for the
calendar year, commencing January 1 and expiring on December 31, of the year in
which the licensee desires to conduct business with the city.
      (4)   Business entities with more than five participating employees shall
pay a monthly fee of $75 and an annual renewal fee of $500.
   (C)   If any licensee has more than one person engaged in the business of
peddling or uses more than one truck, wagon or other vehicle in such business,
or if more than one person is engaged in the business of soliciting, then the
foregoing license fee shall be paid for each of such separate persons, trucks,
wagons or vehicles and a separate license shall be issued for each such
separate person, truck, wagon or vehicle.
   (D)   All solicitors requiring cash deposits or taking orders for cash on
delivery purchases (C.O.D.), or who require a contract of agreement to finance
the sale of any goods, services or merchandise for future delivery, or for
services to be performed in the future, shall post a bond to the City Clerk, on
terms and conditions acceptable to the City Attorney.
(Prior Code, § 10-304) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996; Ord. 2014-06, passed 5-6-
2014; Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-16-2021)
§ 113.05 APPLICATION REVIEW AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Upon receipt of an application, the City Clerk or authorized
representative shall review the application as deemed necessary to ensure the
protection of the public health, safety and general welfare. If the City Clerk
finds the application to be satisfactory, the Clerk shall endorse his or her
approval on the application and shall, upon payment of the prescribed fee,
deliver the required license to the applicant within five business days of
receipt of the application and required license fee.
   (B)   Upon review of the application, the City Clerk may refuse to issue a
license. The reasons for refusal shall be noted on the application, and the
applicant shall be notified that his or her application has been disapproved
and that no license will be issued. A license may be refused for any of the
following reasons:
      (1)   An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information
on the application;
      (2)   The applicant has been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor
involving moral turpitude;
      (3)   There is no proof as to the authority of the applicant to serve as
an agent to the principal; and/or
      (4)   The applicant has been denied a license under this chapter within
the immediate past year, unless the applicant shows to the satisfaction of the
Clerk that the reasons for such earlier denial no longer exist.
(Prior Code, § 10-305) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996; Ord. 2014-06, passed 5-6-
2014)
§ 113.06 EXHIBITING LICENSE.
   Solicitors and peddlers shall have the license in their possession at all
times for exhibition upon demand by any customer or representative of the city.
(Prior Code, § 10-306) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996; Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-
16-2021)
§ 113.07 TRANSFER.
   No license issued under this chapter shall be transferable.
(Prior Code, § 10-307) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996)
§ 113.08 DUTY OF POLICE TO ENFORCE.
   It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city:
   (A)   To investigate all complaints against a solicitor or peddler and to
otherwise examine all places of business and persons in their respective
territories subject to the provisions of this chapter;
   (B)   To ensure compliance within this chapter and to enforce the provisions
of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same;
   (C)   To examine all places of business and persons in their respective
territories subject to the provisions of this chapter;
   (D)   To determine if this chapter has been complied with; and
   (E)   To enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to
be violating the same.
(Prior Code, § 10-308) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996)
§ 113.09 RECORDS AND COMPLAINTS.
   (A)   The City Clerk shall keep a full record in her office of all licenses
issued under this chapter. Such record shall indicate the number of the
license, the date of issuance, the nature of the business, the amount of the
license fee, the expiration date of the license, the authorized place of
business and the name or names of the person or persons authorized to carry on
the business.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall report to the City Clerk any complaints
against any person licensed under this chapter and any convictions for
violations of this chapter, and the City Clerk shall keep a record of all such
complaints and violations.
(Prior Code, § 10-309) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996)
§ 113.10 PROHIBITED PRACTICES.
   (A)   A solicitor or peddler shall be prohibited from: calling at any
dwelling or other place between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. except by
appointment; calling at any dwelling or other place where a sign is displayed
bearing words “No Peddlers,” “No Solicitors” or words of similar meaning;
calling at the rear door of any dwelling place; or remaining on any premises
after being asked to leave by the owners, occupant or other person having
authority over such premises.
   (B)   A solicitor or peddler shall not misrepresent or make false, deceptive
or misleading statements concerning the quality, quantity or characteristics of
any merchandise offered for sale, the purpose of his or her visit, his or her
identity or the identity of the organization he or she represents.
   (C)   No solicitor or peddler shall impede the free use of sidewalks and
streets by pedestrians and vehicles. Where sales are made from vehicles, all
traffic and parking regulations shall be observed.
   (D)   No solicitor or peddler shall make any loud noises or use any sound
amplifying device to attract customers if the noise produced is capable of
being plainly heard outside a 100-foot radius of the source.
   (E)   No solicitor or peddler shall allow rubbish or litter to accumulate in
or around the area in which he or she is conducting business.
(Prior Code, § 10-310) (Ord. 2014-06, passed 5-6-2014; Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-
16-2021) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.11 EXEMPTIONS.
   (A)   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following:
      (1)   Any person who operates an established business at a permanent
location within the city and who has paid an occupation tax or other licensing
fee to the city shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter when
offering goods for sale at places other than his or her permanent place of
business, provided that such goods are the same type as those offered for sale
at the permanent place of business;
      (2)   A person or group of persons selling his, her or their own property
at a garage sale, estate sale, moving sale or similar activity, which said
property was not acquired for resale barter or exchange, and who does not
conduct such sales or act as a participant by furnishing goods in such a sale
more than twice during any calendar year;
      (3)   Any solicitation made upon premises owned or occupied by an
organization upon whose behalf the solicitation is made;
      (4)   Any communication by an organization soliciting contributions
solely from persons who are members of the organization at the time of such
solicitation; and
      (5)   Any solicitation from members or agents of a charitable
organization which is recognized as such under I.R.C. § 501(c)(3), 26 U.S.C. §
501(c)(3).
   (B)   Any person claiming to be legally exempt from the regulations set
forth in this chapter, or from the payment of a permit fee, shall cite to the
City Clerk the legal authority under which exemption is claimed and shall
present to the Clerk proof of qualification for such exemption.
(Prior Code, § 10-311) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996)
§ 113.12 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the Mayor of
the city, after notice and hearing held before the City Council, for any of the
following reasons:
   (A)   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statements contained in the
application for license;
   (B)   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection
with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise;
   (C)   Any violation of this chapter; or
   (D)   Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving
moral turpitude.
(Prior Code, § 10-312) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996)
§ 113.13 NOTICE AND HEARING.
   A license revocation hearing shall be held within a reasonable time of a
license revocation. Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be
timely provided in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the
complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed,
postage prepaid, to the licensee at his or her last known address, at least
five days prior to the date set for the hearing or personally served upon the
licensee at least two days prior thereto.
(Prior Code, § 10-313) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996)
§ 113.14 APPEAL.
   (A)   Any person aggrieved by a decision in regard to the denial of his or
her application or in connection with the revocation of a license shall have
the right to appeal to the city governing body. Such appeal shall be taken by
filing with the Council, within 14 days after notice of the action complained
of, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for appeal. The
governing body shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal. Said
hearing shall be held no more than 20 days from the receipt of the appellant’s
written statement. Notice of such hearing shall be given to such person in the
same manner provided in §
113.13.
   (B)   The decision and order of the governing body on such appeal shall be
final and binding on all parties concerned.
(Prior Code, § 10-314) (Ord. 96-03, passed 3-5-1996)
§ 113.15 SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is for any reason
held to be unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the
remaining sections, sentences, clauses or phrases of this chapter, or the
chapter as an entirety, it being the legislative intent that this chapter shall
stand notwithstanding the invalidity of such section, sentence, clause or
phrase.
(Prior Code, § 10-315) (Ord. 1963, passed - -; Ord. 1031, passed 2-6-1950; Ord.
83-7, passed 4-19-1983)
CHAPTER 114: PAWNSHOPS
Section
   
114.01   Definitions
   
114.02   Record of property received; required; content, preservation of
records and notification
   
114.03   Rates regulated
   
114.04   Disclosure and advertising
   
114.05   Limitation on agreements and practices
   
114.06   Prohibited practices
   
114.07   Requirements
 
   
114.99   Penalty
§ 114.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MONTH. The period of time from one date in a calendar month to the
corresponding date in the following calendar month and, if computations are
made for a fraction of a month, a day shall be one-thirtieth of one month.
   PAWNBROKER. A person engaged in the business of making pawn transactions.
   PAWN FINANCE CHARGE. The act of lending money on the security of pledged
goods or the act of purchasing tangible personal property on condition that it
may be redeemed or re-purchased by the seller for a fixed period of time.
   PAWNSHOP DETAIL. Any officer of the City Police Department who is assigned
to work in connection with pawnshops.
   PLEDGED GOODS. Tangible personal property other than chosen in action,
securities or printed evidences of indebtedness, which property is deposited
with or otherwise actually delivered into the possession of a pawnbroker in the
course of his or her business in connection with a pawn transaction.
   REDEMPTION PERIOD. The period of time from transaction date to maturity date
of a pawn transaction.
(Prior Code, § 10-801)
§ 114.02 RECORD OF PROPERTY RECEIVED; REQUIRED; CONTENT, PRESERVATION OF
RECORDS AND NOTIFICATION.
   (A)   Every pawnbroker shall keep at his or her place of business an
accurate detailed description of all personal property, bonds, notes and other
securities received or purchased and mentioning particularly any descriptive or
identifying marks that may be on such property, bonds, notes or other
securities, together with the name, residence and accurate description of the
person by whom they were left. Such entries must be made on the date such
property is taken in, using ink or indelible pencil, and no entry shall be
erased or obliterated. All such records shall be clean and legible and shall be
made upon special record sheets prepared for that purpose. All such pawn
transaction record sheets shall be approved as to form by the Chief of Police
of this city.
   (B)   Persons subject to this chapter shall file notification with the
administrator of the State Uniform Consumer Credit Code, Wyo. Stat. §§ 40-14-
630 et seq. and pay fees, pursuant to the provisions of Article 6, part 2, of
said Code.
   (C)   All books and records shall be kept in accordance with accepted
accounting practices, and such records shall be preserved or made available in
this state for a period of four years from date of the transaction, or two
years from final entry made thereon, whichever is later.
(Prior Code, § 10-802)
§ 114.03 RATES REGULATED.
   (A)   No pawnbroker may contract for, charge or receive an amount as a
charge in connection with a pawn transaction other than a pawn finance charge,
and except as otherwise provided in division (B) and (C) below, no pawn finance
charge shall exceed an amount equal to:
      (1)   Twenty percent per month on that part of the unpaid balance of
principal which is $200 or less;
      (2)   Ten percent per month on that part of the unpaid balance of
principal which is $200 but does not exceed $400 but does not exceed $1,000;
      (3)   Five percent per month on that part of the unpaid balance of
principal which is more than $400 but does not exceed $1,000; and
      (4)   One and one-half percent per month on that part of the unpaid
balance of principal which exceeds $1,000.
   (B)   A pawnbroker may contract for and receive a minimum pawn finance
charge of not more than $5 where the amount financed does not exceed $75, or
not more than $7.50, on amounts financed which exceed $75. Minimum charges
authorized by this division (B) are in lieu of earned pawn finance charges.
   (C)   Except in the case where a minimum charge is contracted for pursuant
to division (B) above, nor more than one-half of the pawn finance charge for
the two month maturity period may be considered to be earned at the time the
transaction is entered into and is not subject to refund in the event of
prepayment. Following expiration of the first month from transaction date, and
upon entering of the second month of the transaction, the second month’s charge
accrues and may be considered to be earned at that time.
(Prior Code, § 10-803) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.04 DISCLOSURE AND ADVERTISING.
   (A)   Information to be disclosed shall be made pursuant to applicable
provisions of Federal Reserve Regulation Z of the Truth in Lending Act, 15
U.S.C. §§ 1601 et seq. and the State Uniform Consumer Credit Code, Wyo. Stat.
§§ 40-14-630 et seq.
   (B)   A pawnbroker shall not engage in false or misleading advertising
concerning the terms or conditions of credit with respect to a pawn
transaction. Advertising which complies with the Federal Consumer Credit
Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601 et seq does not violate this division (B).
(Prior Code, § 10-804)
§ 114.05 LIMITATION ON AGREEMENTS AND PRACTICES.
   (A)   Even though a pawn transaction subject to this chapter creates a
debtor-creditor relationship, no pawnbroker shall make any agreement requiring
personal liability of a customer in connection with a pawn transaction and no
customer has an obligation to redeem pledged goods or make any payment on a
pawn transaction. The only recourse of a pawnbroker where the customer has
pledged goods is to the pledged goods themselves.
   (B)   A pawnbroker shall not permit a customer to enter into a pawn
transaction in which the redemption period is more or less than two months from
transaction date.
(Prior Code, § 10-805)
§ 114.06 PROHIBITED PRACTICES.
   No pawnbroker shall:
   (A)   Divide or separate a pawn transaction into two or more transactions
for the purpose or with the effect of obtaining a total pawn finance charge
exceeding that authorized by this chapter;
   (B)   Accept a pledge from, sell to or purchase property from a person under
the age of majority as defined by Wyo. Stat. § 8-1-102(a)(iii);
   (C)   Accept any waiver, in writing or otherwise, of any right or protection
accorded a customer under this chapter;
   (D)   Fail to exercise reasonable care to protect pledged goods from loss or
damage;
   (E)   Fail to return pledged goods to a customer upon payment of the full
amount due the pawnbroker on the pawn transaction; or
   (F)   Make any charge for insurance in connection with a pawn transaction.
(Prior Code, § 10-806) (Ord. 92-01, passed 2-18-1992) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.07 REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   No person shall at any time carry on the business of pawnbroker
without paying the required occupational tax in accordance with Chapter 111.
   (B)   Unless a person has first obtained a license from the administrator of
the State Uniform Consumer Credit Code, Wyo. Stat. §§ 40-14-630 et seq.,
authorizing him or her to engage in business of making supervised loans (Wyo.
Stat. §§ 40-14-359 et seq.), he or she shall not engage in business as a
pawnbroker.
(Prior Code, § 10-808) (Ord. 80-28, passed 7-1-1980) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person who engages in the business of operating a pawnshop without
first paying an occupational tax in accordance with
Chapter 111 is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be
punished by a fine not exceeding $200 or by confinement in the City Jail for
not more than 90 days.
   (B)   In addition to the penalties prescribed in division (A) above, if any
person engages in the business of operating a pawnshop without first paying
occupational tax as prescribed in
Chapter 111, or if any pawnbroker contracts for, charges or receives a pawn
finance charge in excess of that authorized by this chapter, the pawn
transaction shall be void and the customer is not obligated to pay either the
amount financed or the pawn finance charge in connection with the transaction.
Upon the customer’s demand, the pawnbroker is obligated to return to the
customer, as a refund, all amounts paid by the customer and the pledged goods
delivered to the pawnbroker in connection with the pawn transaction or their
value if the goods cannot be returned. If a customer is entitled to a refund
under this section, and a pawnbroker liable to the customer refuses to make a
refund within a reasonable time after demand, the customer shall have an action
against the pawnbroker, and, in the case of a successful action to enforce such
liability, the costs of the action together with the attorneys’ fees as
determined by the court shall be awarded to customer.
   (C)   A pawnbroker who fails to disclose information to a customer entitled
to information required to be given, pursuant to §
114.04, is liable to that person in an amount equal to the sum of:
      (1)   Twice the amount of the pawn finance charge in connection with the
transaction;
      (2)   Two hundred dollars, whichever is greater; and
      (3)   In the case of a successful action to enforce the liability under
this division (C), the costs of the action together with reasonable attorneys’
fees as determined by the court.
(Prior Code, § 10-807)
CHAPTER 115: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
Section
Liquor Licenses Generally
   
115.01   Definitions
